Though I am a long time lurker on this forum, some of you may know me from elsewhere. Here is a system I have been trading. Additional nuances will follow soon. I eagerly welcome all of your comments (and complaints).   
  
_Construct a template according to the following settings_ :  
8 EMA (yellow, dotted)  
12 EMA (violet)  
24 EMA (cornflower blue, hence the name)  
72 EMA (khaki)  
  
Apply to H1 (conservative) only and remove the grid for clarity.  
  
**System principles**  
Cornflower is based on the principle that trades should be taken when the same trend presents itself on multiple timeframes. On an hourly chart, the 24 EMA obviously defines the daily trend. The 8 EMA, which is one-third the length, shows the intraday velocity of “fast” money. A 12 EMA shows the trend of the last half-day. Its value is a place at which price will typically find support when there is a dominant trend. To a lesser extent, this also applies to the 24 EMA. A long-term trend will sometimes catch a breather around this area, with big money accumulating on the opportunity to buy or sell at a substantial discount. Finally, the 72 EMA defines the dominant trend in the market. This trend will reassert itself as cumulative memory persuades traders to resume trading in its direction. If the three shorter-term averages are above the 72 EMA, we are in an uptrend and should not go short. The same applies in reverse for a downtrend.  
  
Cornflower can be used in a number of ways by all kinds of traders. When price pulls back to the area between the 12 and 24 EMAs, the opportunity for a short- to medium-term bounce presents itself. We can enter and set a profit target based on a number of criteria, be they support and resistance areas, pivot points, or a set pip amount. Or we can enter a longer-term trade, perhaps exiting when the 12 EMA crosses down below the 24 EMA. The longer-term setups in this system are powerful and can yield hundreds of pips on a single trade that will last for up to two weeks. Cornflower will catch every major move in the market, providing multiple opportunities to take advantage of a big trend and pretend that one is a bank trader.   
  
**Basic System Rules**  
****  
**(_Note 11/27/08: I no longer take signals from the initial "aggressive" 30M entry. Use at your own risk.)_**  
****  
There are two kinds of entries using this system: pullback (conservative) and initial (aggressive). The pullback entry, which is the heart of this system, enters the market when conditions are quiet and after price has settled into the area between the 8 and 24 EMAs. The timing of this entry can either be mechanical (using either the 12 or 24 EMA) or discretionary in accordance with the trader’s judgment on whether price is moving back in the direction of the trend.   
  
The initial entry aims to capitalize on the first movement of a new trend, defined by a thrust beyond the 72 EMA that is confirmed by a turnaround in the shorter EMAs. It is more risky because there is always the possibility of a reversal. For this reason, it is probably better to use the M30 chart for this type of entry. Moved up by 30 minutes, one has the opportunity to take a small profit or scratch a trade at or near break-even if a reversal presents itself.   
  
Only the H1 and M30 charts should be used with the Cornflower template. Shorter time periods will lead to whipsaws, whereas longer time periods lag behind the market too much.  
  
The following rules are valid no matter the time of day. The quiet of the Asian session actually provides some excellent opportunities for entry, which is a boon for the trader whose day job makes watching the market during London or New York an impossibility.  
  
_Pullback (conservative) entry_ – use hourly chart  
·8, 12, and 24 EMAs are all above (long) or below (short) the 72 EMA  
·Price has pulled back to the 12 or 24 EMA (the more aggressive the trend, the more shallow the pullback.  
·Enter for 20 pips, or hold depending on trader’s judgment of the strength of the trend.  
  
_Initial (aggressive) entry_ – use M30 chart with identical indicators  
·Price has moved with authority above or below the 72 EMA. By “moved with authority,” I mean a candle that has closed near the top of its range.  
·8, 12, 24 EMAs are all pointed in the direction of price, and preferably already stacked in a perfect order (8 over 12 over 24 for long, 24 over 12 over 8 for short).  
·Enter for 20 pips and hold if the thrust develops into a real trend.  
  
Using hourly and half-hourly charts, 20 pips is a realistic initial profit target, especially if one is trading GBPUSD, GBPJPY, or EURJPY. Even the other major pairs should yield this much on a properly gauged signal. By “major,” I mean EURUSD, USDCHF, AUDUSD, USDJPY, NZDUSD, and USDCAD. With the possible exception of EURGBP, any pair that involves two of the seven major currencies should be tradable with this system. Cornflower is particularly well-suited for entering long positions on the yen crosses (carry trades).   
  
Entries may be timed more precisely with a 5M timeframe. More on this later.

Usd/Jpy 1 hour   
  
Enter   
_Initial (aggressive) entry_   
72 Ema trend setter only trade with him at your back  
24 Ema is the wall to deside the trade.. got to get over it.  
the wall must have the trend setter at its back  
8 Ema is the bird dog to - warn of an up coming trade..  
12 Ema is the trigger man   
When the trigger man & the bird dog go over the wall   
& with the trendsetter at their back ....you are in   
  
_Pullback (conservative) entry_   
Sames as the ( Initial (aggressive) entry )  
  
but this time the 12 ema trigger man waits in ambush for price to come back into his line of fire  
price touches or passes through & comes back through again  
The trigger man always wants to be between price & the wall 24 ema  
with the wall 24 ema between him & trendsetter 75ema   
when he takes the trade   
  
**Exit**  
you are out when the trigger man & bird dog come back over the wall   
or trendsetter comes over the wall after the trigger man & bird dog![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

James, when the short averages are not in sync with the 72 EMA, there is no signal. On the 30M I am looking for 20 pips. Sometimes I will simply TP there. Or, you can use classic support and resistance. Some would use fibs and pivots, but that's not really my thing because it's essentially voodoo. But hey, if voodoo can make money, by all means. The 30M signals will sometimes turn into full-fledged trends. Whether to hold is a matter of discretion. I personally would look to take a nice profit, then wait to see if we get a bona fide hourly signal.

It seems we think alike and I look forward to reading about your system. Traders delude themselves into thinking that tools such as price-derivative indicators, pivot points, and fibonacci retracements give them some kind of control over the market. They are merely tools, and fallible tools at that. As Vantage said, there is no substitute for the time-tested concepts of following trends, buying or selling on pullbacks, and using support and resistance. That is all you need. Conversely, you don't need it all. Compound 10, or even 5 pips a day, and you are well on your way to financial freedom.  
  
Trailing stops can certainly be used with this system. If you take the long-term approach, once you are in profit by a certain number of pips you can place a trailing stop at a price level that would cause the 12 to cross the 24 in the direction opposite to your trade. (That is the long-term exit.) I use Cornflower to enter short-term trades for, yes, 15-20 pips. I just took 17 on the breakout from 2.0040, and I am content not to take another trade today. However, I encourage the readers of this thread to use the longer-term version of this system, as short-term trading requires more nuance and skill, which can only be gained through experience.

I am still detailing the nuances of this system, which is why my entry is not clear. This was not an initial entry on the M30 chart, but rather a 72 EMA bounce on the 1 hr. Quite often price will consolidate around the 72 EMA. So long as price does not break down below the 72, the trend is still in place, and when price breaks out from the consolidation area around the 72, we have trend resumption and can trade that break. Anticipating the break, I put in an entry order at 43 (40 + spread) about 2 hours prior to the move. I took profit using the M5 chart. I will post regarding short term charts this weekend. I want to emphasize, however, that you do not need the M5 to successfully trade this system.  
  
All 3 short-term averages are moving back up. Eventually we can look for a pullback entry in accordance with the hourly rules. It might take a while, though.

I had some one ask me if i was making fun of this system  
and I would say not at all.  
  
it is a basic MA crosses   
He has added to it the 2nd & better idea " of bounce or break"  
  
Most traders have used some form of this   
I don't think I have ever used 8,12,24,72 emas  
\- have used 5 ema 12ema(13 ema, 8sma) 24 ema(25 ema) 72 ema (75 ema)   
and with good M.M. they all work & you will make lots of money.  
  
two tricks I have found that may help   
on any "MA bounce or breaks" systems  
that give you a better in & keep you out of bad trades  
ie getting chopped to death are  
  
1\. if you are trading on the 1 hour chart   
.. when you get the set up you want   
drop down to the 15 min chart   
put a sars on it & let the sars be the enter sign   
you will get a better price   
& miss about 30% of the bad trades.  
I like this one  
  
2\. if you want to keep it all on one chart   
put on a slow stoch at 14,3,3 low/high   
and only trade with it   
& again it will miss about 25% of the bad trades.  
  
don't do both it will only confuse the issue,  
I have tried![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f641.png?v=15.1) ... do one or the other  
  
so again I was just having fun ...   
what I said was how I first was able to understand   
the MA crosses - breaks or bounces.  
  
I was hoping it might help some one   
& to be honest I was a little borded

It's late in the day, but GBPJPY, EURJPY, and USDJPY are all signaling long on the 1 hr. The crosses are volatile. GBPJPY requires a **100** pip stop if you are trading longer term. That thing can move 50 pips in the blink of an eye and it's not for the faint of heart. EURJPY is good for a carry play with a stop of around **70** pips.  
  
GBPUSD, my speciality, has bounced again off the 72 EMA, though I would not enter right before Friday close. It looks very similar to how AUDUSD did earlier in the day before it took off.

In addition to the two entries I descibed previously, there is another way to enter trades. Price will decline to the level of the 72 EMA, causing the shorter EMAs to turn around. It then finds support at the 72 EMA, consolidating for the better part of a day (if not more), and establishes a trading range. We can anticipate a break of that range back in the direction of the trend, placing an entry order at the top of that range, plus 1 pip, plus the spread. This was how I entered my trade on Friday.   
  
When we are in a swing trade, and we see price starting to stall, we need to anticipate the price level that would cause the 12 EMA to cross back under or over the 24 EMA. We can either calculate this algebraically (a pain without an MT expert indicator--hint hint), or simply draw a trendline once we see the shorter EMAs begin to flatten out. I am a fan of Tom Demark's "TD" trendlines. We draw the trendline from the most recently established significant low or high _back_ in time to the previous significant low or high, and place a stop loss order (NOT a take profit) at that price. Sometimes the EMAs will cross without breaching the trendline, and we simply exit. But violent reversals do present themselves, and we have to be ready:  
  
[http://img145.imageshack.us/img145/5...pybreaksr0.gif](http://img145.imageshack.us/img145/5311/eurjpybreaksr0.gif)  
  
  
Notice how I also drew a trendline on the highs. Declining highs are a warning sign. When price fails to break out from a trendline drawn on them, a reversal may be at hand. Indeed, you could have exited before the lower trendline break when you saw the bull trap and subsequent sell off. But it takes experience to properly judge these conditions.

It would not follow the rules of my system. Cornflower breakout entries are identified on the 30M chart according to the rules I set out.   
  
That said, trendlines are a solid tool, and your strategy is certainly one way of trading the breakout. There is nothing wrong with combining my system with other tools; just be aware that you are trading something different and must follow rules of your own devising. You can trade a trendline breakout, exit at a logical place, and then look for a Cornflower pullback.   
  
Though I encourage traders to make this system their own, try to avoid overcomplicating things. We don't need 12 different indicators to validate a trade or exit. At a certain point, you have to take the trade if the setup is there. If you lose, on to the next setup.

There is really not a lot to it. You wait until price has pulled back on the hourly, then look for a resumption of trend on your M5 chart when the market is active. A break of a lazy range or channel is one simple way to do it, perhaps with a stop on the opposite side of the channel. Igor Toschchakov's _Beat the Odds in Forex Trading_ details many setups of this type. Like me, he is adverse to excessive indicators. He posts here as Igrok.  
  
Another method is detailed by Phillip Nel:  
  
<http://forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=11854>  
  
The system I use is remarkably similar to Phillip's and I recommend you read up on his method.  
  
Aggressive trends pull back to the area between the 5 and 10 EMAs. Philip's is an 10/21 pullback system. Same principle. Gauge the speed of the trend and trade accordingly. Bollinger bands (20,2) are good for this. They widen when velocity speeds up, and contract when price slows down. When price begins to travel on the outer band like a monorail, you have an aggressive trend and should expect few pullbacks. Otherwise, wait for a good price.  
  
Finally, one must always be aware of the previous day's high and low, and areas of support and resistance. S&R is the founding principle of technical analysis. Ignore at your peril.

I am so pleased that forum members are having success trading Cornflower. Thank you all for taking the time to read and learn about my efforts.  
  
Cornflower can be traded purely off the 1H chart. But here is my 5 min chart, which I use to time entries:  
  
<http://img95.imageshack.us/img95/834/5mingf5.gif>  
  
The settings are:  
  
5 EMA (blue, thicker)  
10 EMA (dark orchid, thicker)  
21 EMA (maroon)  
50 EMA (black)  
Bollinger Bands (20, 2 in black dotted)  
Background color: 214,168,105   
  
Before I discovered Philip Nel's system I just had the 5 and 10 EMAs. The 21 does a nice job of showing the way price is going. On the the hourly chart, you would wait for the usual pullback to the 12/24 EMA area, then switch to the M5 and wait for trend resumption as indicated by the 5/10 EMA combo and price movement.   
The active trader can trade the pullback to the 10 EMA, so long as it is supported by the 21 EMA, and in the direction indicated by the hourly chart. Your stop would be a close below the 21 EMA. You can scalp using this chart, but if it's moving nicely you can certainly get 10-20 pips, if not more.  
  
An aggressive trend will pull back only to the 5 EMA, and will sometimes just ride up the outer BB (as we see here with the reversal on Friday). You have to know when to trade the pullback and when to ride the rail, which is something that you can gauge only through experience. I also watch 1 minute candles, but more on that another time.  
  
Again, this 5M method is not at all necessary to trade Cornflower. Think of it as another tool. I have attachment capability now, so here's the template for both this and Cornflower hourly.

Again, I want to emphasize that this aspect of my system is completely optional, especially if you are trading longer term. However, short-term traders can benefit by combining the hourly Cornflower with a shorter timeframe.  
  
The idea in using the 5-min chart is simply to time the entry more precisely. It is in keeping with the concept of multiple timeframe trading. When price reaches a key EMA on the H1, we can look to the 5-min to see whether price is resuming the trend. This eliminates some of the guesswork involved as far as whether to enter on the pullback to the 8, 12, 24, or even 72 EMA.   
  
The 5-min chart has different settings than the hourly, which I detailed in post #89 (I also attached a template). On the 5-min, we want the 5 EMA to have crossed over the 10 EMA (and preferably over the 21) to verify a long bias. We obviously want the opposite order for a short bias. If the 5-min bias is counter to trend shown on the H1 chart, _we do not trade_. Only when the ducks are lined up _on both charts_ do we have a trade possibility. Quack.  
  
The rules for entering on the 5m chart as follows:  
  
1\. The 5 ema will have crossed over or under the 10 ema. Price velocity is increasing, and the pair has perhaps broken out of a sleepy trading range. In other words, _it is clear from the movement of the price that the hourly trend has resumed._  
  
AND  
  
2\. Price pulls back to the area around the 10 ema. We wait until price resumes trend direction a second time, and then we enter. This resumption can be indicated by either a strong close in the direction of the trend, or _clear and distinct movement in the direction of the trend_. Sometimes price will only pull back to the 5 ema. Whether to enter on the 5 or 10 EMA is up to the trader. Again, experience counts here.  
  
OR  
  
3\. We simply hop on the train if price is moving too fast to wait for a pullback. This is the case if nearly the entire body of the 5m candle is coextensive with the outer bollinger band line.  
  
Exit at your discretion. Possible exit signals are a short doji that is floating entirely outside the outer BB, or a 5m candle with a nasty wick pointing opposite to the direction of your trade. Or you can get out at 15-20 pips. Or, hold in accordance with the hourly rules and exit when the 12 crosses the 24 on the hourly chart. Do not exit at a loss if you have 20 pips. Some would quibble with me on this (give the trade a chance, let your winners run, don't stop believing, etc.), but I am not one to let a profit turn into a loss. The best trades never do anyway.   
  
Some might be tempted to take the countertrend trade on a doji or wick. Don't get cute. We are trend traders. Leave the scrounging to others.  
  
A reasonable stop is below the 21 ema. You can always try again. OR, if you are trading longer term, 50 pips for cable, 70 for EURJPY and USDJPY, 100 for GBPJPY and GBPCHF, and perhaps 40 pips for the other pairs. When trading longer term, _your lot sizes must be smaller to account for the wider stops_. The small trade size is compensated by larger pip gains. Preserve your capital.

lever70,  
  
I've already thanked you here before and told you that I use your method, but in a different light. Since it has been so successful for me, I thought I'd share with everyone my way of trading your method. And if it is deemed inappropriate or irrelevant, then let me know.  
  
I'm not sure if anyone has read Jacko's thread in Journal Factory, but let me be the first to tell you that it is a million units in gold. Simple, but extremely effective. Combined with your entries, it is basically Pipsgiving with a fat pip-turkey.  
  
I use Jacko's method to determine the trend:  
  
1) Daily chart  
  
If Price goes from bottom left to top right, the trend is up. If price goes from top left to bottom right, trend is down.  
  
2) 3-Hour chart (4-hour would work, I'm sure)  
  
If Price goes from bottom left to top right, the trend is up. If price goes from top left to bottom right, trend is down.  
  
3) 1-Hour chart  
  
If Price goes from bottom left to top right, the trend is up. If price goes from top left to bottom right, trend is down.  
  
I know what you're thinking... DUH. That's what I thought, too.   
  
Now, if all three timeframes are in an uptrend, then use your entry method for long entries as usual. Vice versa for shorts.  
  
My sole issue with your method was its Risk:Reward. 50 pips risked for 20 pips gained means you better be pretty darn accurate and generate a lot of wins. So, what I do is let the trades run until I look at the hourly chart and it no longer shows the trend I'm in. This improves the Risk:Reward greatly; especially when you are jumping in a long-term trend.  
  
Basically, if I'm long and the hourly chart is going from top left to bottom right, then I exit.  
  
  
Why am I telling you this? Because I am up 667 pips from the beginning of last week. This represents a 32% increase of my account all in one week and a half's time.   
  
Thanks again and I hope this helps,  
  
Kevin

Look at a current GBP/USD 1HR chart.

Zoom it all the way in- you have a marked downtrend.

We don't trade crosses. Crosses merely indicate trend direction. We pullbacks/trend resumptions from key EMAs, or the breakout from the 72 EMA on the 30M chart, or the breakout from a congestion area above or below the 72 EMA. The longer term exit is the 12 crossing the 24 on the 1 hr chart.  
  
As for EURUSD, I would not enter a position the day before NFP after the peak of the NY session. In fact, let's make that a rule:  
  
**No new positions are to be entered after 10am NY Time on the day before non-farm payroll. Holding positions is at the trader's discretion, but an exit is recommended if you are in profit.**  
  
Expect a lot of choppiness until NFP and perhaps a pullback to the 72 EMA.

I understand where you're coming from, and it is only fairly recently that I myself ditched the indicators. If I were a purist, I would not even use EMAs, which are still indicators. I like EMAs because they help me see where price is going. But to truly gain confidence, I think you need to get rid of all of these other indicators and start learing to trust the entries. I have given the 5M template to help with timing, but I don't think you'll really need anything else except perhaps a glance at some longer term timeframes to gauge the strength of the dominant, long-term trend. I also think classical technical analysis is great (support and resistance, anchors, trendlines, chart formations). But if you put too many "stop lights" on your trades, you will miss some excellent opportunities.   
  
Some of the charts that people post in threads here at FF really crack me up. All sorts of indicators and lines and stuff...after a while they start to parody themselves.

As far as knowing when it's going to bounce, a 5M chart comes in very handy and I've given some pointers on how to use it. Basically, you want to see that the trend is resuming. A short-term chart allows you to see this much sooner than the hourly.  
  

> Quote
> 
> Disliked
> 
> When trading a MA cross you normally have a low or a high to use as a stop, but on the pullback to the 24 sometimes the placement of stops is not clear to me. How do I place the stops on a 12 or 24 bounce trade?

  
We're not trading MA crosses. The placement of stops all depends on how long you plan to hold the trade. If you are going for a sustained move in the direction of the trend, I recommend the following:  
  
GBPUSD, EURUSD, USDCHF: 50 pips  
USDJPY, EURJPY: 70 pips  
GBPJPY, GBPCHF: 100 pips  
AUDUSD, NZDUSD, USDCAD, and most other pairs that exhibit lower volativity: 40 pips.  
  
If you are going for a short term trade, use the 5M to time entries precisely such that the trade won't go against you more than 10 pips. You should try to make 20 pips, but get out sooner if it seems as if the trend might be reversing. Don't let a profit turn into a loss, _ever_.

If you are trading ONLY on the hourly chart, it is not necessary to wait for the candle close, and doing so will prevent you from entering at a discount. You can put an entry order at the 12 or 24 EMA, depending on the angles of the shorter EMAs. If the angle is steep, go for the 12 EMA. If it's shallow, go for the space between the 12 and 24 EMAs, or just the 24 EMA.   
  
Pullback vs. trend changing: the 5M helps with this. Please see my previous posts on how to use it.

End of day report. I will try to start doing this every day to maintain interest in this system. _All traders should be aware of orange and red colored news announcements when they trade._ A major economic release or statement can completely alter the market picture.  
  
"Long" and "short" indicate the current bias. Traders should look for pullbacks to the 12/24 EMA area and/or use 5M to time entries in the direction of the trend.  
  
_Major USD Pairs_  
  
EURUSD - SHORT. At 8 EMA.  
GBPUSD - SHORT. Aggressive start to trend. Pullback (PB) may be shallow here.  
USDCHF - LONG. Short uptrend, look to 8/12 EMA area for entry.  
USDCAD - NEUTRAL. Has switched to LONG on the 30M, but the downtrend has been strong. However, the pair is bouncing off 30-year lows, which correspond with its natural floor at 1.10. We're not going to see 1.00 before the Fed or BoC intervenes to lower the loonie.  
AUDUSD - LONG. Has bounced off 12 EMA. This pair is very high. Be careful.  
NZDUSD - NEUTRAL. Has been in aggressive uptrend along with AUDUSD.  
USDJPY - NEUTRAL. 30M is switching to long.  
  
_Yen Crosses_  
GBPJPY - weak SHORT. I do not like trading against the carry, but the chart doesn't lie. Is hanging around the 24 EMA. If it goes above 238.75 it is neutral. Start looking for an initial long on the 30M or an authoritative resumption of the downtrend.  
EURJPY - weak SHORT. Above 162.60 it's neutral. Very similar picture to GBPJPY.  
AUDJPY - LONG. Bounced off 24 EMA.  
NZDJPY - NEUTRAL. Has gone to sleep.  
CADJPY - NEUTRAL.  
CHFJPY - attractive SHORT at 12 EMA.  
  
_Other Crosses_  
AUDNZD - LONG but a very wicky chart with little movement.  
EURAUD - aggressive SHORT. PB to 8/12 is shortable.  
EURCAD - SHORT - any PB to 24 is shortable.  
EURCHF - LONG. Look for 24 PBs.  
GBPCHF - LONG. An overlooked pair with good volatility.  
GBPCAD - SHORT. Not for the faint of heart. Use 100 pip stops.  
  
Happy happy, trade trade.  
-f

The prices for the two pairs I cited are simply a few pips above the recent highs. If they move above those figures there is a high probability that they will retrace all the way to the 72 EMA, i.e., enough that we would get a long signal on the 30M.

This is indeed a very interesting topic. In fact, the Yen carry trade phenomenon is fairly recent. Japan had interest rates at zero for years before currency traders decided that the carry trade was the hot thing. It is all going to end in tears before too long. Japan's economy is awakening from its long slumber slowly but surely. When people wake up to this fact, the yen will increase, slowly at first, and then with great acceleration. It should not be of great concern to short-term players. But there are billions tied up in these speculative trades...there is going to be a lot of money lost (and made). Hi all, I just wanted to share my backtest results with you on this system. I did this on the 1 hour only with pullbacks to at least the 12EMA as an entry. For an exit I waited until the 12EMA actually touched the 24EMA. Once in I stayed in until the exit and didn't reenter at pullbacks which may give you better results. Many timies getting out using your own discretion would have given you more pips. I tested this from April 2nd until May 7th. YThere were 8 trades, 4 wins and 4 losses for a total pip profit of 399. Thank you Felicia...you go!!

Here is the 30M chart of CHFJPY:  
  
[http://img526.imageshack.us/img526/4...flower6tp3.gif](http://img526.imageshack.us/img526/4873/cornflower6tp3.gif)  
  
At the time I posted, around 7pm NY time, it had just signaled an initial long entry, with an authoritative close over the 72 EMA. Always look at the 30M as well as the hourly. These 30M signals generate optional intraday trades, preferably timed in conjunction with the 5M. The long-term holds come from the hourly. If anything, when you see the 30M signal to go long, you should definitely not take the short on the hourly.   
  
The hourly never signaled long because of (B). The 24 EMA must have crossed above the 72 EMA. This would have kept you out of a bad trade, with JPY very strong today on news that BoJ governor Fukui is looking to shift to a more aggressive interest rate policy. Also, the short EMAs had all turned up on the hourly. All of these signs pointed to the pair going up, or at least sideways.

I used to countertrend trade using certain candle patterns in conjunction with indicators. It only worked part of the time, and going against the trend drove me batsh*t after a while. It is partly why I have grown so distrustful of indicators. So now I only trend trade, and Cornflower is what I trade the great bulk of the time, timing my entries with the 5M. There are some discretionary nuances to my trading that I haven't shared, only because they are not easily systematized, and I don't want to confuse all of you. Nothing I have omitted is essential to trading the system profitably.   
  
I have mentioned previously that sometimes I use a 1M chart. I am a scalper at heart, and the Guppy multiple moving average system is one of the best entry systems out there for short-term trading. I have developed my own way of using it:  
  
[http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...34&postcount=3](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=1428434&postcount=3)  
  
Guppy can be used with or without Cornflower, but I always prefer to trade with the dominant trend. This is purely optional, for the ADHD-afflicted like myself. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)

Yes, they're all EMAs on the close. Pip goal depends on time of day and market velocity. I am content with only a few pips if the market is slow. If it's really chugging along I can get 20+ on the guppy. Average is 10-15.  
  
I am kinda sorta full time. I am a part-time college prof, which gives me the luxury of being able to watch the market almost whenever I want. Hopefully I can quit that gig by this time next year, if not sooner. I am essentially self-taught, much like all of us here. I did belong to a live trading room for a time, where I learned a great deal from some very kind, intelligent traders.   
  
Guppy was originated by Australian trader Daryl Guppy and taught to me by a trader who has 55 years of experience in the markets. That's longer than most of our EMAs. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1) The stories he has are fascinating. In short, he thought it was the best entry system he had ever seen. I modified it with different colors to create the crocodile jaw opening and added the 200 EMA as a trend filter. Now he is using my version. Cornflower and the "5/10" (my 5-min) are of my own devising, though they are really nothing original from a conceptual standpoint.

Elder's books are excellent. I suppose there is a passing resemblance between the systems in that I wait for the 5m to match up with the hourly. But again, I stress that this is not necessary. You can trade the hourly by itself.  
  
News plays a big role in my trading. I do not take a new position right before a red-colored announcement. Even the orange-colored ones can move the market on a substantial deviation from consensus. News is only a factor for GBP, USD, AUD, CAD, and occasionally NZD. JPY news doesn't really impact the market much, and EUR news doesn't impact it at all. GBP and USD are the two currencies most affected by news.

Good question. I would say the following:  
  
1) Flattening EMAs are never a good sign. It means price action is stalling. You want a well-oiled Jaguar, not a Dodge Dart.  
  
2) A chart whose EMAs fit the criteria, yet whose pattern is sloppy and ill-defined. You want nice, steady movement.  
  
3) Long wicks all over the place. Wicks pointing against the direction of your trade is a good thing; it indicates that price successfully repelled an area of potential supply, with ample buyers stepping in. Long wicks in both directions means that the market is undecided as to what the price should be, so you have traders buying and selling and scalping and generally passing the crack pipe. Crack is wack.  
  
4) A strong candle close that causes the 8 and 12 EMAs to point opposite the direction of your trade. Stay out.   
  
5) Short EMAs stacked opposite to the direction of the 72 EMA. Stay out.

I have only been trading the system for the last couple of months, so I don't have that kind of track record. Properly gauged entries have usually been profitable for me. It helps if you use the 5m template in conjunction with Cornflower proper. That way you are not going short when the pair looks like it's going up.

Nice trade. Your identification of support at around 1.3436 was more significant than any single indicator on your chart. As I have said repeatedly, I don't use these indicators, and having three of them on your chart is not going to give you any more certainty than having none. They do nothing except trace a line in accordance with a mathematical formula derived from price. When they appear to predict a move, it is merely coincidental.   
  
What I _do_ do is time my entries in accordance with a 5m or 15m chart. See posts 71, 89, 97, and 193.   
  
Indicators are a crutch. Kick them to the curb.

If you are going to follow two pairs, I suggest that one be a non-dollar pair that does not involve the Yen. This way you will have trading opportunities in non-correlated markets. EURUSD looked lousy for an entry. It was basically trendless.  
  
In the beginning of this thread I posted regarding different kinds of entries. Somehow that post got deleted. So here we go again:  
  
[http://img297.imageshack.us/img297/8...examplebd0.jpg](http://img297.imageshack.us/img297/8153/cfexamplebd0.jpg)  
  
**#1** : On December 5th, price thrusts down below the 72 EMA and a new downtrend begins. Price pulls back all the way to the 24 EMA, providing an opportunity for a short entry. Price then declines 60 pips, providing ample opportunities for profit-taking. Then on December 6th and 7th, price pulls back to the 12, 24, and 72 EMAs in turn. A new trend is sometimes risky to trade because traders are still deciding whether a new trend exists. So long as this indecisiveness is apparent, the previous trend will try to reassert itself. However, if one were to trade the first 12 EMA pullback, there is still a 30 pip decline before price ascends to touch the 72 EMA.  
Notice how the shorter EMAs don’t unravel, even though price retraces all the way up to the 72 EMA. You can assume that a trend is still intact until the shorter EMAs turn around in the other direction. When that does happen, you should switch to a 30M timeframe and wait for an initial signal in the direction of the shorter EMAs. If they had turned around here, you would not want to have entered short. As it happened, price bounced off the 72 EMA and started moving down again. Once the 8 and 12 EMAs dip below the 24 EMA, we know that it is safe to enter short.  
**#2** : December 7th gives up an example of a 12 EMA bounce. There are two opportunities for short entries for at least 20 pips.   
**#3** December 8th gives an example of why one should be out of the market before non-farm payroll. GBPUSD shoots up over 100 pips on the NFP announcement. Once the announcement hits, however, we have a clear entry to go long and an opportunity for at least a 20 pip profit before a violent retracement takes cable lower again.   
**#4** December 10th gives a nice example of a 24 EMA entry. But it also gives us an example of volatility. If you had placed an entry order at the 24 EMA, you would have been dismayed to see price going nearly 30 pips against you before turning around. This demonstrates the importance of risk control and money management. Cornflower is not a system that allows you to trade at 200:1 margin on every trade. You must allow you positions time and space to work. This is true of any system that takes its signals from longer term charts. We will discuss entry timing techniques later in this document.   
**#5 and #6** are examples of a slow uptrend. When price is slowly moving in one direction it pays to wait for a 24 EMA pullback. There are three such pullbakcs here.  
**#7** shows price finding support after a steep selloff. The 72 EMA represents the average of three days of price activity, and price very often finds support here.

Here is a question I received in a PM:  
  

> Quote
> 
> Disliked
> 
> Hi Felicia  
>    
>  Thanks for sharing the system. Need some advice from you.  
>    
>  How do you judge whether the uptrend or downtrend is still on-going prior your entry at the retracement at 12ema or 24ema??? when the ema 12 turns flat???  
>    
>  I can't bring myself for entry cos I don't know when to get out the trade....  
>    
>  Thanks!

  
  
The trend is still in tact when the EMAs are still in a perfect order. When the 8 crosses the 12, the trend has paused. When the 12 has crossed the 24, the trend may be ending. It is OK to enter on a pullback so long as these conditions don't exist.  
  
As far as exits go, the 12/24 cross is a firm exit. Otherwise, it's up to the trader. You can use classical support and resistance. You can measure the average daily range of the pair to determine where the move might run out of steam. You might perhaps have a daily pip quota you shoot for, exiting when you have reached it. Others use fibonacci and pivot points. It is up to you to find exit criteria that make sense.  
  
Good luck!

I continue to be amazed at how many people are studying this system and trading it with success. I think the last 6+ weeks of posts and trades show that trading need not be complicated. Identify a trend, wait for a good entry point, and trade. Hold until the trend is no longer in place, and then on to the next trade.  
  
I would like everyone to have a look at Kharvell's trading journal, which has now become a laboratory for the Cornflower method as combined with Jacko's trend-following techniques. Kevin started using Cornflower in April and has had some amazing success using the method. He uses low leverage and trades multiple positions in different pairs, as well as multiple entries on the same pair when a new pullback presents itself. His trading exemplifies how I think Cornflower ought to be traded from a longer-term perspective:  
  
[http://www.forexfactory.com/showthre...=19102&page=21](http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=19102&page=21)  
  
The only difference between his and my way of trading Cornflower is that he does not take entries that are out of sync with the long-term trend as exemplified by a daily chart, whereas I will take such entries. For instance, he did not trade EURUSD and GBPUSD in May because the downtrend in the hourlies did not accord with the uptrend in the dailies. This is perfectly valid, and one can expect much larger gains when the hourly is in sync with the daily. Study and learn from his trades.

I do not use the Cornflower settings on a 5M chart. I use 5, 10, and 21 EMAs, so I would not be looking at the 12-24 EMA cross. See posts 71, 89, 97.  
  
When to exit depends on how you are using Cornflower. If you are trading longer-term, use trailing stops. One possible method: when you are up 30 pips, move the stop to break even. When you are up 50 pips, move the stop to 20 pips. Keep trailing up and make the trail tighter the more pips you have. And there is the 12-24 hourly cross, as well as the 30M entry,which can be used to exit the hourly trade taken in the opposite direction.   
  
If you're using Cornflower primarily to set up short-term trades, your entry has to be precise and your exit should be gauged by an estimation of how far the move will go. This differs for each pair and you should study each pair's past behavior and "personality." You should be aware of the pip value of the average daily range, for instance. Currency pairs have a strong tendency to, in the words of Igrok, "complete" their ADR in a given trading day. Thus you can exit when the ADR has been reached.  
  
You should always be aware of support and resistance levels. These can be used to exit.  
  
You can also simply exit when you have acquired a set number of pips for the day. The problem with this method is that it does not compensate for losing days. When the move is strong, you will want to stay in past your quota so as to compensate for days where a pip is as rare as a white pigeon.  
  
Finally, you can exit when you get a 5M wick so nasty, it could impale you like an ice pick. This indicates exhaustion.  
  
Also, pay attention to correlations between pairs. When a correlated pair starts moving aggressively in the opposite direction to your trade, you might take this as an exit signal.

(resubmitted message with proper, corrected templates)  
  
Many of you have been asking about exits. Felicia never stops working.  
  
I am unveiling, on a TEST basis, revised Cornflower templates that include profit bands. These bands are drawn at set distances from the 72 EMA and vary for each currency pair. They are based on my knowledge of 8 pairs and can serve as _approximate_ profit targets. Mind you, they are unscientific. But what is in technical analysis?  
  
For each pair, there is a P1 and a P2. P1 is the likely limit of an average move, defined by a trend that tends to pull back to the area shy of the 24 EMA before continuing its trend. P2 is the target for an agressive move that pulls back only to the 8/12 EMA area. P2 moves are not as common.   
  
The 72 EMA excursion values for each pair are as follows:  
  
_Template CF50_  
EURUSD, USDCHF, USDJPY, AND USDCAD: P1 = 50; P2 = 75 (edit: correction)  
  
_Template CF70_  
GBPUSD, EURJPY, and EURAUD: P1 = 70; P2 = 100  
  
_Template CF100_  
GBPJPY: P1 = 100; P2 = 150  
  
Surely bands could be devised for other pairs.  
  
Please note: pairs will not always reach these targets, especially in weak ranging markets. Use your discretion.

Simon, I used to use this very same setting on the hourly. I also used a 8,3,3 on the 5-min. There were times when it appeared to presage a change in direction. But in the end, I decided that it was no more helpful than looking at candle patterns and support and resistance levels to determine where a given move might end.   
  
The reason why I have come to dislike indicators is because they are (a)pseudo-scientific, and (b) hope-inducing. You can change the settings all you like and you will find one that appears to forecast price. Then you try and use it in real time and it doesn't work nearly as well as you thought it would. Hence the never-ending search for the perfect indicator that will work all of the time. There is no such thing. Only price is reliable as an indicator of market direction.

I have just finished reading through your thread....it has motivated me to continue with my trading rather than throw in the towel. I have worked hard to achieve success but like many others have had mediocre results.  
  
The lessons that I have learnt here is to take smaller profits, your charts show clearly using simple EMA’s, which way the market is moving with strength, you are correct in saying that most traders use far too many indicators and this causes uncertainty in their   
minds.  
  
I believe that your teaching of using the principle of compounding is a valuable one particularly for the younger traders who believe that every trade has to achieve maximum pips to make real money…..the key is to take small regular pips, in theory you can double your investment every week by just taking 20 pips per day from the market.

That might be too long, depending on where you entered and how far the countertrend move has gone. You can use the profit bands, the 12-24 cross on the hourly, support and resistance, and the completion of the pair's average daily range (which would mean you would be in and out several times in a strong trend). Flattening EMAs on the hourlies are also a good exit signal. You want to try the anticipate the trend has likely exhausted itself.

I'm a noobie in FX, and have been studying various threads since March.  
Having followed this thread from the beginning, loaded up MT4 with the templates, studied the charts, read and re read my notes....I took the plunge this morning on Cable.   
Seeing a pullback starting on the H1, with 20 mins left of the hour, I anticipated the price would go back to the 12ema and duly placed a limit buy order at that level - 1.9843. The order was filled (I had placed a stop @ 20 pips) and the price went on up after first touching the 24ema. I exited this evening @ 35pips gain....  
  
Felicia - thankyou for sharing this approach - I like its simplicity and it has helped to clear my head which was becoming overwhelmed with multifarious indicators,etc. I do recognise the need to be aware of trendlines and S/R which can help set short term targets.  
Don't let the negative posts get you down - people who want to be successful at FOREX appreciate your time.  
Enjoy your break and relax in the meantime.  
  
.....B

Just to elaborate a little more on what I'm doing . . . I'm just trying to follow the Cornflower system as closely as possible . . . nothing more, nothing less.  
  
I tend to look at possible trades twice a day: around 10 a.m. EST, when prices seem to have a tendency to retrace and offer some entry points before resuming the trend, and then again around 4 to 7 pm EST, as Felicia suggested, when trading slows down.

I like this Guppy template as it identifies trend/sideways more visually at a glance. Copy and paste in the /templates folder and apply to your charts.  
  
Guppy was referred to in Lever70's post somewhere as useful template for M1 scalping but it is well applicable to any time frames, H1, M30, M5...

I just started looking at this system this last week. No screen shots but around 80 pips on demo. eur.chf, eur.usd and usd.jpy. And I booked 15 pips from the gbp.usd earlier this week (live account) and of course it was the only time that it was in the chop (6.20.07) I entered on dip exited on the drop when it closed just below the 12ma. My rule is "always exit when it closes above or below the MA I have determined."   
  
As far as the demo trades, I only booked half because I was watching it to see how it played out with no stops and targets.   
  
I plan to back test all weekend and apply a 2 unit test.  
Unit one will target 10-20 pips depending on previous high/low. Once 1st target is hit, I will close 1 and move the 2nd to break even and use a MA as second exit. That MA hasn't been determined yet. I am also thinking about using a MA as stop loss instead of a pre-set.   
  
I know some reading this may say that's to tight. I agree, but once I earn the pips, they are mine. Not the markets to play with. I get up way to early and spend to much time back testing to consider it anybody elses.   
  
As my confidence in the system increases, I will increase units and MA's for stops.  
  
I have already back tested other systems like this, but were more of the MA cross based. So overall I am pretty comfortable with it and the learning curve has already been established. The back testing is going to be more for understanding the personality of the currencies than anything else.  
  
I left the cross based systems because of the unreliability over the long run, but now I am back because the only things you really need are S&R and price action.  
  
PH

Since it's a demo account, I'm just using 1 mini-lot for each trade. I used two targets this week to see how often I reached the first target but missed the higher target. This week, though, both targets were always hit on the winning trades. I'll probably continue to experiment with that for a while to see if there's any value in having a lower first target.

I didn't develop the system, so perhaps Felicia will want to reply to this when she returns, but the whole point of a trend retracement system is to allow a trend to develop and then take advantage of the inevitable pullback.  
  
If any of us could consistently predict when "point A" would develop on any chart, we'd have the holy grail. Since we usually can't do that, the Cornflower system allows us to do the next best thing: Recognize that a trend has developed, and then enter at the pullback. The adage in trading is "buy the dips and sell the rallies". The Cornflower system gives you a predictable way to put that into action.  
  
Did you lose some potential pips my missing the entry at "point A"? Yes, but it appears to me that both your "point B" and "point C" entries offered nice pip potential and definitely would have been winnable trades. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)   
  
In regard to your next post (#429), I may have missed it, but I didn't see where Felicia ever suggested closing a trade when the 8 EMA crossed the 12 EMA on the 30 min chart.  
  
Good luck in your trading. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)

Not exactly. I may not have been clear in my first post. I will usually set my stop 10-20 pips below the 72 EMA on the 30-min chart. Once that's done, I'm don't often look at the charts again for several hours. So, I'm not concerned about where the candle closes. When I return to the charts, if my stop has been hit, that trade's history. If it's moved up but has not hit my target, I'll adjust the stop loss again so it continues 10-20 pips below the 72 EMA, thereby reducing my potential loss.  
  
Most importantly, keep in mind that these are NOT Felicia's rules. She may return and say that I'm dumber than rocks. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f633.png?v=15.1) At this point, I'm just experimenting on a demo account and that stop loss method worked well this week.

I mainlly trade the Cable. If you look at a weekly 60m chart you can see that price when trending almost always pulls back to a fibo moving average--the consistency is remarkable. I monitor my trades on a 10m chart--again the 5ema is a great guide while in a trade. I use the fib numbers with price support and resistance . I have found this to be quite accurate. Also it seems to work in any time frame. However keep in mind that this is a trend-following system.

I have been reluctant to post to the thread for fear of complicating Felicia's elegant system - so in the spirit of not wanting to add something irrelavant, the example below shows something i've been using to identify potential entry points. I first mark the 1h chart with the significant red vertical bar to indicate the retracement close that i'm watching... during a trend. Then I mark the same line on the shorter time frames. The horizontal bar shows the opening price of the following bar on the 1h chart. I then mark that on the shorter time frames. I have found that this shows important information about support or resistance developing around the key MA's.   
  
In the example I chose, the trend for AUDCAD is up so i'm inclined to pass on the sells. I'd be waiting for a long entry, however this is simply my personal trade strategy. Hope this is useful to the system.

Euphoricism - I'm been wrestling with this one for a couple of years now. Bottom line: there is no easy answer, and no way you will avoid getting stopped out (short of not setting stops - DON'T try it!). I have decided that I either have to go for a short nippy trade, or a good long one - I have found that moving stops to breakeven mostly just stops me getting any profit, so when I'm feeling nervous about the market, I just prefer to take a small profit and run! Good advice I think is, especially while you are learning (and that is definitely still me), set modest profit goals and don't mess with your stops. But other people will maybe advise differently, and in the end it is up to you to work out your own comfort zone.

I made +65 pips on a long Eur/Jpy trade today. I had my charts setup for Cornflower but I actually took the signal based on what looked to be a good entry for a long position trade with an inverted hammer candle forming on the day chart. When I saw that, I started looking down into the lower timeframes and saw literally EVERY ONE showing a solid upward trend with current upward price action. I mention it here because its another example of #1. The value of trading WITH the trend... and #2. The value of using multiple time frames to confirm price action and the overall trend direction.   
  
I also took +13 pips on a Usd/Jpy Short and that trade WAS a true Cornflower pullback exactly to the 12 EMA on the H1 chart. This setup was also confirmed by a spinning top candle at 12:00 noon EST. The M30 chart had a near identical setup with pullback to the 24 EMA line. I entered short at 122.50 and the move was over in about 10 minutes. The move went for +20 pips and I exited manually for +13 pips after retracement began. My charts are posted below.  
  
I was very pleased to have some good results today and I look forward to posting more as I go along. The trend definitely IS your friend...just gotta find the right place to get onboard. Cornflower seems to be a winner where that is concerned! Today is my first day of trading Cornflower (and keeping Jacko's method in mind as well) and I'm up +78 pips for the day. Thanks Felicia!

Hello Tdion,  
  
After reading the Cornflower thread that led me over to Kharvell's thread, I eventually found Jacko's thread from that one. When I was done with all of that reading, I had the deepest impression that Cornflower would dovetail very nicely with Jacko's overarching trading principles. It seems to me that Cornflower is a very nice method of getting a visual representation of what Jacko does...trading WITH the trend and finding a good spot to get in. Jacko doesn't like EMA's or anything more than a 50% fibo line, support/resistance lines, trading at round numbers in price action, and buying the dips in the major trends. However, I like what I SEE with Cornflower and will use it along side all the other tools that work for ME...  
  
I don't recall seeing any charts posted in Jacko's thread from what I recall, so I don't know what one would look like other than just a nice, smooth uptrend/downtrend on a Day/Week/Month chart. I prefer the nice, steady looking trend lines of about 30-60 degrees. But remember Jacko's definition of trends:  
  
\---------------------------------------------------------------------  
DETERMINE THE TIME FRAME THAT **YOU** WANT TO TRADE.  
  
1\. If the graph on the chart starts in the bottom left hand corner and ends in the top right hand corner, **the market is going UP**.  
  
2\. If the graph on the chart starts in the top left hand corner and ends in the bottom right hand corner, **the market is going DOWN.**  
  
3\. If you are still confused, print it off and show it to a 5 year old...they will get it right EVERY time...LOL  
  
The trend is the BEST friend you will ever have in the Forex market.  
  
When you trade with the trend, even if you make a mistake, the market will get you out of your problem....If you make a mistake and you are fighting the trend ...YOU ARE STUFFED, BIG TIME !!!  
\-------------------------------------------------------------------------  
  
I have personally been doing my trades with Jacko's trading principles in my head as I use and apply Cornflower. Also, I'm not strictly using Cornflower only on the 30M and 1H charts. I also use it on higher timeframes and will take trades from those as well, so long as there are multiple time-frames providing confluence. Also, if you identify a trade entry on the higher TF's, the lower TF's can help you dial it in a bit so you can maybe avoid having to suffer a drawdown until the trade goes your way.   
  
I generally will look at a pair from the Monthly chart downward to get the long term bias for the pair. Then as I move downward to shorter TF's, I try to find a Cornflower setup, usually in 1H or 30M if I can, but will also take a CF signal on the H4 or daily chart. Someday, I hope to be trading from the Weekly and Monthly charts with longer term positions, but not until I gain a bit more confidence in what I'm doing and how I'm reading the signals. So far, so good, but its very early in the process... ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60e.png?v=15.1)

Hi Tdion,  
  
Jacko explains it pretty well, but I personally use the same template on the 4hr and really not even that. I use trendlines starting on the monthly and this is how it goes.  
Monthly - Dotted line (red)  
Weekly - Solid (red)  
Daily - Yellow  
4hr - Blue  
  
I then look for support and resistance areas. What I have done and seems to work well is during my back tests of different ideas is, I go back at least 2 years of data. While I am doing my tests, I place an infinity parallel line at major areas of S&R and leave them be.   
Sometimes price will hit those months later, well be on your one or two monitors and you will be the wiser.  
  
Or if you use a different chart service for testing and trading, just jot down the S&R numbers and then place them on your chart. Many times they are whole numbers.   
  
I feel more comfortable and profitable going in the direction of the Red lines. I will still trade the blue and yellow if they are going in opposite direction, but I will be less tolerant of trade if it goes against the Reds.   
  
Hope that helped,  
PH

Hi Kevin,  
  
I'll give it a whirl for you. Sounds like you and I learn in similar ways. I can get a pretty good handle on the concepts and have it pretty straight in my mind, but I also need to have the visual frame of reference to solidify my thinking.   
  
These charts are on the H1 timeframe and represent Cornflower setups as described in Lever70's first post in this thread where price has pulled back against the prevailing trend and has touched or entered the area between the 12 and 24 EMA's.   
  
I think the text of Lever70's first post actually says that price should pullback BETWEEN the 12/24 EMA's. So, someone please correct me if I'm wrong, but I think it was said later in the thread that a "touch" of the 12 EMA was also acceptable. Either way, the signals I've shown here were good trades.  
  
  
<http://www.creations4christ.com/forex/cf-long.gif>  
  
  
<http://www.creations4christ.com/forex/cf-short.gif>  
  
  
Once a Cornflower trade signal is identified, I think the difference between a good setup and a poor one has more to do with whether the trade you see forming IS or IS NOT confirmed by the higher and lower timeframes immediately surrounding H1. I also prefer taking H1 trades that are in the direction of the prevailing longer term trend from at least on the Day chart. It also helps if the M30 and M15 charts are headed the same way. If you are working with a nice, steady trend on the H1, then the surrounding timeframes should provide a confluence correlation with the H1. I don't like working with trends that are too steep or too shallow, somewhere between a 60 degree to 30 degree slope works best for me.   
  
I also rely a lot on candle formations around the Cornflower signal points. I notice a lot of hammers, dojis, and spinning tops that seem to form where these signals occur. Just more confluence of indicators to point the way...  
  
Best wishes on your trading!

I just realized that I had described and posted charts for only ONE type of Cornflower entry....the conservative PULLBACK entry. There is also a more aggressive entry called the INITIAL entry. This involves a signal from the M30 chart where price action moves across the 72 EMA and a candle closes "with authority" (meaning the close was near the top or bottom of its range). Also, the 8/12/24 lines should already be stacked in correct order prior to crossing the 72 EMA following price action.   
  
Here is a chart with an example.

Hi Generalz,  
  
This is just my non-professional opinion, but for me, a "touch" of the 12 EMA line is enough for an entry signal (although it's a less conservative approach) PROVIDED THAT.....  
  
#1. The CF signal points to the direction of the prevailing overall trend on the H1 and higher charts.   
  
#2. The lower charts (at least M30) also support the direction of the H1 move, which I find they usually do if the H1 chart already has a nice steady ongoing trend at the time of the signal.   
  
I think the more conservative approach would be to wait for the candle which made the signal to close. This will also give you the opportunity to see if that particular candle turns out to be an exhaustion or reversal candle, such as a doji, hammer, or spinning top which would give you even more confidence that price was going to move ahead in the direction you want it to go. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

I was going over the charts earlier and found this setup in progress, left over from the close of trading on Friday... I don't trade Fridays after about noon or so EST, so I didn't see it until today. Considering the weekend break, I'd wait for more confirmation that price was going to move UP before taking a position, but this signal meets the CF criteria. Note the final hammer candle with the very long wick. Also, you can see that price had deflected off the Daily R2 resistance level pivot point, came back down to the Daily R1 and then bounced back up, making the previous R1 a SUPPORT level now. These are good indications of where price might be headed when trading reopens, but I would have preferred an entry closer to the 166.50 area. Also, the higher TF charts support a long entry and several of the lower TF's do too. We'll see where it goes...

Also, you can see that price had deflected off the Daily R2 resistance level pivot point, came back down to the Daily R1 and then bounced back up, making the previous R1 a SUPPORT level now. These are good indications of where price might be headed when trading reopens, but I would have preferred an entry closer to the 166.50 area. Also, the higher TF charts support a long entry and several of the lower TF's do too. We'll see where it goes...

The market analysis methodology exposed by the cornflower system is a revelation to me. It has not yet transformed my trading results but it most certainly has transformed my perception of price action. I see the cornflower system as an analysis framework within which to view the market action. I am so grateful to lever70 (and you other contributors) for the quantum leap in my FX education. In the spirit of sharing, I have attached a mt4 EXPERT (not an indicator so put it in the experts folder) which will alert when a predefined ma is touched. The default ma is 12 but you can set it to anything. Upon ma touch, a sound (news.wav in sounds folder) will be played and an arrow drawn on the chart. I consider myself an average fx trader but a gun mt4 programmer so I am only too happy to enhance the EA with sensible features.  
My mt4 setup comprises 2 profiles:  
1\. A Master profile with 10 pairs in tabs on H1 timeframe  
2\. A Detail_View profile with 4 mini windows on H1, M30, M15, M5  
Using function key F5 in mt4, I can switch from Master to Detail_View and back again for any pair. This gives me a full screen H1 chart + 4 mini windows when needed with a single keypress.  
Cheers  
rjb

Hi Kev-K,  
  

  
Yes, I think paper trading is an excellent idea for beginners and pros alike anytime you are trying out a new system. At the very least, you can also just work with a free demo account and take your "licks" there. Either way, I think there are folks here with MUCH more experience than myself who would tell you not to try ANY system with LIVE funds until you know it front and back in demo/paper trading! And then...just when you feel that overwhelming urge to "GO LIVE"...sit back and demo trade for another 6 months MINIMUM!   
  
I think this is a very simple system to learn and that is a definite PLUS! In our quest to make Cornflower "better", I hope we do not forget the "simplicity" that it holds, which I feel is one of its best features. I've seen a lot of criticism about MA systems (mainly "crossovers", which Cornflower is NOT), but I have to say that I really think Lever70 has got it goin' ON with this one!

You very well could be right. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1) My purpose in sharing losses publicly as well as wins is in the hope that other traders will analyze the trade and perhaps learn something from it that can be applied to their own trading.  
  
Would I take the same trade again? Probably so. The pair was trending up before moving into the sideways pattern or channel. A channel is usually considered a continuation pattern, and the breakout will be in the direction of the trend more often than not.  
  
My thinking was that the trade fit the parameters of a Cornflower trade, and responding to the signal has resulted in a lot more winners than losers for me lately. As it turned out, price ended up testing the 72 EMA before resuming the trend, and I was stopped out.  
  
Oh well, enough self-analysis for one day. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)

2\. In the above situation but with price showing no signs of returning back to the uptrend and the shorter EMAs all having reversed, is it necessary to wait for price to break below the 72EMA before considering a Short trade.  
  
3\. Again, using 60 min chart and presuming an uptrend, what is the trigger for a Long trade. Do I have to wait for price to break back above the 12 EMA and if so, do I wait for the candle to close or is it just discretionary ie. guessing and hoping if there is no additional signal such as price hitting strong support or a reversal candle signal.  
  
Thanks to everyone here for giving up their valuable time to help others. Until I saw this system, my trading has been just the "Triumph of Hope over Experience" Hopefully thanks to Cornflower this will now change.

Do I have to wait for price to break back above the 12 EMA and if so, do I wait for the candle to close or is it just discretionary ie. guessing and hoping if there is no additional signal such as price hitting strong support or a reversal candle signal.  
>

1) Yes - the EMAs must be all aligned in the same direction. If not, it's a no trade.  
  
2) Yes - the 72 EMA is what determines the trend. Above = long, below = short.  
  
3) You can enter at the 12 EMA. You do not need to wait for a break. If you have a job, for instance, you can simply put an entry order there. Traders who can actively watch the market should use the MTF cornflower (60m, 30m, 15m, and 5m). Remember money manegement. Do not over-leverage yourself if you can't actively watch what is going on. Trade smaller, but aim bigger.

Hi Yen44x,  
  
I think you'd be hard pressed to find a situation where there was a Cornflower pullback signal without at least some reversal of the 12/24 EMA lines direction. This one just happened to also be a strong pullback well below even the 72 EMA. The danger with this trade was that it could have represented a full reversal had it continued. IMHO, a safer entry would have been to wait until the close of the NEXT 1H candle which turned out to be an inverted hammer which strongly signaled shortside exhaustion and the move upwards. Glad he made the 40 pips though, that's what counts!

My main point was that in this case, on the GBP/USD trade for example, the 12 EMA had crossed the 24 EMA, which would be a signal to close a Long trade per the Cornflower method rather than open one. In addition, all of the EMA's were heading in the wrong direction for a Long signal, and had been for almost 24 hours.  
  
In regard to being "hard pressed" to find a Cornflower signal without some reversal of the 12/24 EMA's, take a look at the GBP/USD uptrend from 6/27 to about 7/3. There are numerous opportunities to enter Long without any reversals on the 60 MIN chart.

You should close these trades immediately while you have profit. We should not be trading USD in the hours before NFP! Also, we have GBP news in less than 30 minutes. You must pay attention to the news calendar.  
  
As for limit orders, yes, I have done this, and it's perfectly valid. The angle of the EMAs should determine whether your entry order is placed at the 12 or 24 EMA. The steeper the angle, the shallower the pullback.

Hello to all. Attached is a MT4 custom indicator file. Very basic functionality is implemented in this version. I named it the MA Proximity Sensor (MAP Sensor). It's a simple indicator that will alert you by playing the sound alert2.wav once the price reaches (or the price change occures) in definable distance from a moving average. The period and type of the MA can also be set. Price used for the MA computing is always the CLOSE price.  
In this first version of MAP Sensor the alert is played even if the price breaks through the MA. So it will keep beeping while the price jumps around the MA +/- the pips distance.  
If anybody needs more than one MA to be monitored by the MAP Sensor, simply drag more of it on the chart and configure each.  
  
Usage:  
1) copy indicator files into MetaTrader_folder\experts\indicators and start Meta Trader  
2) open a chart of your choice  
3) in the Navigator window find Custom indicators and scroll down to MA_ProximitySensor and drag it on the chart  
4) click the Input tab. The variables meaning is:  
  
**exMaPeriod** \- the length of the MA period  
**exMaType** \- a textual (string) variable, which can be one of these: _ema_ , _sma_ , _smma_ , _lwma_ lower-case. In a case of any other string the fallback MA type is _ema_  
**exMaVisible** \- whether to draw (true) the MA or not (false)  
**alertPipsDistance** \- the distance in which the sensor starts beeping  
  
Any ideas are appreciated. I'll be unreachable from tomorrow till the end of July.

Because the EMAs had not yet lined up correctly. They had all intersected and it wasn't until the following hour that they did line up correctly.

I have been following this thread very closely and would like to say how enjoyable it is to see support coming from so many traders for each other's benefit. I am familiar with the use of multiple time frames to take the Cf trades that occur during trending markets but in spite of looking at multiple time frames, I've always felt like these entries still carry more risk than I'd like. I have also studied Jacko's thread extensively and very much agree with all of his points, as well as many of Trader888's points. The one minor contradiction I see with the objectives of those 2 trader's approaches and the Cf system is simply the profit objective. Keeping that in mind but employing the most significant guide of the long term trend as the major filter, I have been using fractals (also known as swing points or TD points).   
  
Before anyone goes crazy thinking this is another indicator... it's not. All it does is identify key market events - when a higher high and higher close is followed by a lower high and lower close or vice versa - These prices, while seemingly obvious, are not so easy to notice at a glance. This indicator will alert a trader to these key prices. On the chart I have attached, I show a classic (or so I believe) Cf trade that I took this morning. It shows the swing point and the entry point.   
  
I welcome your feedback. I'm only offering this because I think it supports this system in a very unintrusive way and suggests better places to be entering the moves. I employ other criteria for the actual trade but I believe that this can be very helpful. In addition, if you set the indicator for the time frame (1h) you can switch it to a shorter time frame and it will give the swing point for the given time frame.   
  
You will also notice that I have employed the fine template made by Pipskateer. Thank you sir for that!  
  
Sorry if the image isn't clear. I had a problem with getting good resolution...  
  
Joe

Here's what I recommend for every Cornflower trader, especially novices:

  1. Go back and read every one of lever70s posts.
  2. Never even look for a trade before a major news release or speaker, or on Fridays after 11am (NY Eastern time).
  3. When you find a suitable trade on the H1 chart:

    1. Initiate your trade when the price retraces to the 8EMA (if the price is moving up/down quickly) or between the 12-24EMA (which covers most cases).
    2. Set your Stop Loss at exactly 10 pips.
    3. Set your profit Limit at 20 pips (10-15 pips if the pair historically does not move very far).

  4. Walk away from your computer and let Cornflower do the rest.

_Exception: If proper money management enables you to trade more than one lot, take your profit on half of your lots, move your Stop Loss to break-even on the other half. Then go for the ride, trailing your Stop(s) as you go._  
  
The benefits of sticking to this practice religiously:

  1. You'll become one of the most disciplined traders in the industry.
  2. You'll eliminate all of the emotions that cause most traders to lose money.
  3. You don't have to worry if your stop loss gets hit and then the price moves again in your favor for what might have been a profitable trade. **Cornflower will give you many more profitable trades than losses.**
  4. By setting a 10-pip Stop Loss, you will eliminate the possibility of watching the price go against you and holding on hoping for it to reverse in your favor. This is probably the major cause of major losses in trading.
  5. By setting a 10-pip Stop Loss, you'll never have to worry about spikes.
  6. You don't have to worry that you 'only' gained 10-20 pips whereas the price eventually moved up/down for a 100 pip gain. Remember the story of the Turtle and the Hare - the Turtle wins the race - not the rabbit.
  7. You will avoid the temptation of trying to make as much money or as many pips as you can. The idea is to gradually increase your account balance like the pros do. Not adhering to #4 and #6 will eventually cost you dearly due to fear and greed.
  8. You'll discover that trading can be a relaxing, enjoyable and rewarding experience without taking too much time away from your other important activities (like family). ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)

PS. You can quote me in your upcoming book, lever70. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f647-200d-2642-fe0f.png?v=15.1)

Paste the copy of the screenshot there and your screenshot will appear. He can also select one part of his screenshot by using a symbol on the left side (the _**square dot**_ symbol). Hi everyone,   
  
There was a great trade at 7pm US time for 60 pips. I follow felicia's system faithfully and have learned the hard way never to try and predict what the market is or isn't going to do. At 7pm the trend was angled perfectly, between 30 and 60 degrees, and the market pulled back to between the 12 and the 24 Ema's. Have also found that there is almost always a good trade at some point during the Asian market especially Monday trading.  
  
I place a breakeven at 15 pips, take 80% off the table when I reach 20 pips and then let the 20% run on until the cross over of the 8 and the 12 Ema's in the opposite direction. This info was shared by a good member almost at the beginning of this thread.  
  
If another trade appears I trade again with the same system even though I may still have a trade of 20% in the system. Should mention that I almost always wait for the market to reach the 24 Ema unless the angle of the trend is steep. This was another little gem that was shared earlier by a generous member. I also never risk more than 2% of my capital. It's a very relaxing sytem. Thanks again Felicia, it's an amazing little/big pip winner.  
  
I'm all finished for the day. Time for family.  
  
Happy pipping to all,  
  
Happy ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Hi Joe,  
  
Again sorry for the delay. I live on the other side of the world and only watch the UK and Asian markets. Mostly I set the alarms and enter using a market order because I can then decide exactly where I want to enter and make any necessary stop loss/breakeven/profit adjustments. I always place a 10 pip stop plus spread from the 24 Ema. My spread is only 1 pip for all major currencies. If I get stopped out then I have only lost 10 + spread pips and can then decide if I should re-enter where I was stopped out if the market is still looking good. If the market moves too fast and I miss the entry point by a pip or two then I still enter because I then place a breakeven at 15 pips profit from where I should have entered - at the 24 Ema. Almost always the 20+ pip profit is reached and if not then I have lost nothing or only 11 pips max. I still take 80% off the table at 20 pips and let the remaining 20% run on especially if it's a new trend. My computer is on all the time with alarms set for where I expect the market to return to for a good entry. I don't watch it all the time only when the bells ring. A quick check of the charts will tell me if I have a few spare hours to wander away for a while. Hope that helps.  
  
Good luck trading today.  
  
Happy.
