I know that many of you would like me to produce a PDF detailing the system. I hope to produce such a document by this time next week. Due to time constraints, it will not be as detailed as I would like. But it will have the rules, some pictures, and remarks on the nuances of trading Cornflower. As others have remarked, there is no substitute for reading this thread. The collaborative effort of many posters has even helped me in the trading of my own system.   
  
Cornflower has not really changed all that much in three months. Post #1 is still valid. There are my posts about how to use the 5/10 impulse entry, and also the 1-minute Guppy Multiple Moving Average. These could both stand alone apart from Cornflower as feasible entry systems; I simply don't take trades counter to what the H1 or 30M CF charts tell me. There is also the multi-timeframe 60/30/15/5 setup, which gives you the luxury of waiting for the most high-probability opportunity. Some go even further and do not take trades that are counter to the prevailing daily trend. But everything follows from that first post. I have always tried to discourage posters from using any indicators other than the EMAs, sometimes rather sternly. Indicators look good on paper, but lag the market and they will cause you to lose money or miss profitable opportunities. The EMAs are closely correlated to the actual price action.  
  
Money management is important. If you are going for larger pip gains that correspond to the profit bands and/or support and resistance levels, you should not leverage yourself more than 10:1. It's also perfectly valid to use CF for short-term pip bagging. If you are going for 20 pip gains, 50:1 with a 10 pip stop is the most you can risk. But you can't walk away from the screen. You must must be _vigilant_ about taking small losses when the trade does not work out. Once you are up 10 pips, make sure you exit that trade with at least 2 pips of profit. By contrast, when going for larger gains you have to be prepared to let the trade go against you before it goes your way. GBPJPY, for example, can easily go against you 50 pips before you see 150 pips of profit. On the whole, do not over-leverage yourself, wait for the right opportunity, and make some pips.

sweety 78901,  
  
1\. go to menu [on the top of your screen], click "window", then click "tile horizontally" or " tile vertically" from the drop-down sub-menu; all different time frame windows which are currently open for this currency pair, will appear in smaller size tiled next to each other in the main window.  
  
2\. minimize the small time frame windows, which you don't need to be tiled up [by clicking on the leftmost square in the top right of the small window; it has an underscore "_" displayed on it]; now you should have only m5, m15, m30 and h1 left open.  
  
3\. repeat the step 1 and you will have only these four time frames tiled in the main window the way you wanted it.  
  
4\. if you want to shift these 4 small windows around to change the order of their appearance in the main window, you need to drag their corresponding tabs [located at the bottom of the main screen] to position tabs from left to right, which will yield the counterclock-wise position of the small windows starting from the left top corner of the main window; then repeat step 1 to achieve desired positioning of the small windows.  
  
5\. go to menu [on the top of your screen], click "file", then click "profiles" from the drop-down sub-menu, then choose "save as"; in the pop-up dialog box type the name for this currency profile [for example, eur usd] and click ok. you should have this name appear at the bottom center of the main window.  
  
6\. repreat steps 1 through 5 for all currency pairs which you trade, and you will be able to flip through them by clicking f5 button on your keyboard to go to the next, and shft+f5 to go to the previous profile; you can also click on the profile name in the center bottom of the main window, and click on the profile names directly from the drop-up window which will appear; you will also be able to rename, save and delete profiles directly from there.  
  
7\. when you are done close the mt4 platform and open it again - this saves all the changes you have made.  
  
i did not mean to insult you by sending such a detailed manual, just want you to set everything up error-free. however, in order to become fluent and proficient with the platform, i suggest you to experiment with mt4, push all the buttons and see what everything is and what it all does [while demo-trading of course ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)].  
  
best wishes and good luck...

As I'm sure you know, calculating the angle of MA's on MT4 is a very subjective thing. Because of the scaling the platform does to allow you to see all of the candles, you don't get a true representation of the actual angle of an MA. (See first chart below.) If you check the "Scale fix One to One" in the chart properties, then you can see something very close to the true angle. (Second chart below.)   
  
Here's what I would like your opinion on. I've written a routine that calculates the angle pretty accurately. But what angle do we want? Do we want the true angle of the MA's based on scaling 1:1? Do we want angles based on what we're seeing on the screen even though the angle that's displayed is correct for what your seeing, it's not the true angle based on price. As an example, it's entirely possible to look at your chart and see the 72ema at something like 10 degrees. Then turn on "Scale fix One to One" and the angle changes to 30 degrees. Both are correct for what you're 'seeing', but that's two different angles for the same data. Which to use?  
  
I can write it either way. It can be written so that the angles that you 'see' are what's calculated. Or I can write it so that the angle that's calculated and displayed is the 'true' angle based on 1:1 scaling, but not based on what you may be observing.

> Ignored

It simply means the distance a given pair can be expected to travel from the value of the 72 EMA, measured in pips. For GBPUSD, for example, P1 is 70 pips from the value of the 72 EMA at the time of entry.   
  
This is something I have been meaning to comment on. If you use the profit bands, it is safer to use the targets that are evident at the time you enter the market. While it is true that the bands move with price, you are better off taking your profit based on what the values of P1 and/or P2 are _at the time you enter the trade_ , instead of revising your targets upward as the trade moves in your favor. Chances are the market will pull back to the 12 EMA, and you can enter again at a lower price after you have taken your band-based profits.

I've been watching this thread with great interest, and finally decided to try it out on demo.  
The following 2 examples are on the 30m charts, and I hope I've interpreted the rules correctly for this TF.  
Both trades open on (or just above) a pivot line, with the specific targets arrowed.  
GBP/USD targets are obvious, but with such a strong upward trend, and the price standing well away from the 8ema, it seemed prudent to let it run. The result was around 118 pips or so, which was encouraging. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)   
EUR/USD also provided a strong run up, which I allowed to pass my target, and I probably would have let it run further, except for that nasty upper shadow on my eventual exit candle. Candlesticks RULE!! The result was a 36 pip profit.  
Please feel free to point out any errors in judgement on my part, folks. This has turned out to be a fantastic system, as well as a lively and interesting thread.  
To Felicia...many thanks indeed for sharing this with us.  
Cheers

Hi WS, and thanks for your comments.  
  
As I said in my post, I really was hoping that I was "sticking to the CF rules", but of course, if I wasn't, I needed to be told. On reflection, maybe I could have entered both trades a little earlier, but I'm one of those people who believe that Pivot Lines have an important place on one's charts. I just needed to see a "healthy" cross of a Pivot Line in both cases before I was happy to enter the trade. Sometimes, a break-out can look a fantastic prospect, but if it comes to a sudden halt and you don't use Pivot Lines, then you'll never know what the reason was! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f615.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/2753.png?v=15.1)   
  
For the benefit of anybody who wants it, I'm posting the indicator below. WS168, just enter it into your MT4/experts/indicator file, and then open up your MT4 platform and look for it in your indicator list.  
  
Thanks again.

Hope you don't mind, but I thought this chart would help any newbie out there who's a bit confused concerning exits. I took this trade below the black arrow as the price crossed the 72ema. Seeing as how it was just under the Pivot Point, and well above the M2 line, it was a good R/R situation. However, the thing that concerned me as the trade developed was the long lower shadows on the preceding candle, as well as the one I was involved in. A sure sign that the Bears were fighting back! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f633.png?v=15.1) I got out of the trade as the next candle kicked in, and I'm glad I did, seeing as this next candle turned out to be a spinning top, and definitely not good for the nerves! As I type this, the price continues to move sideways above the S1 line, so it'll be interesting to see which way it eventually goes. Exits can be S/R lines, MA crosses, breakouts of Trend lines etc., but sometimes it really does pay to take notice of the actual candlestick. It can give you so much valuable info, trust me! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)

Hi WS168.  
Glad you like the Pivot indicator. Yours isn't showing the M1, M2 etc., because you have to set it up. Right click on the chart and select Indicator List. Highlight MultiPivotV2 and click Edit. In the resulting window, scroll down until you see "Mid Pivots". It will say "False" at the side, so double click where it says "False" and you'll get the alternative "True" dropping down underneath it. Click on "True" and then close the window. When you get back to your chart, you should see the Mid-point lines quite clearly.  
  
Sorry, but I can't help you with your GMT+2 question. I have no idea how you'd get around that, as I'm in the UK, which is at present GMT+1. Perhaps somebody from outside the UK can help you on that.  
  
It would be impossible for me to answer your question about broker prices etc., as they all differ, and there's so many of them! People on this forum who are more familiar with different brokers than I am would be the best to ask.  
  
Cheers

Sorry, mate. I meant to reply to this in the last post!   
  
Scalping is merely getting in and out of trades in a matter of minutes, with hopefully a small profit, as opposed to entering a trade, and then sitting back and letting it go for sometimes hours at a time!!  
  
Some traders don't like scalping, yet others love it. It all depends on one's mentality and whether or not one fancies sitting at the screen hopping in and out of trades, one after the other.  
  
When people say they're scalping, they're usually using 1m or 5m charts and never anything over that. It's fast and furious sometimes, and either fun or a right pain in the ass, depending on which way you look at it!! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)   
  
I wouldn't recommend it until you're a bit more experienced, mate. OK? ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)   
  
Cheers

Hi again, WS.  
Thanks for understanding, my friend.  
Re yesterday's trading..........I read earlier in this thread that Felicia (Cornflower's creator) was at heart a scalper, so I decided to try a bit of scalping with Cornflower on the 5m chart. You can see the results below. Of course, it helped having a really good trending market yesterday. If it was like that every day, we'd all be millionaires in no time at all!! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)   
  
I didn't open my first trade until the first candle under the correct sequence of MA's, and my target was the Pivot Point, which, as you can see, it hit with no problem at all. 17 pips profit after spread.  
I then waited for the next opportunity......a candle to find resistance at, or pierce, the 10 ema. If you look at how the price is coming down between the first yellow arrow and the 2nd yellow arrow, and see how it relates to the blue Pivot Point, it seems to take the shape of a descending triangle, so I didn't enter the trade until it had passed through the Pivot Point, reducing my profit to 9 points. I exited the trade after the spinning top, which is always a good place to exit!!  
I entered the third trade as the candle passed back through the 10ema and ended up with 13 pips profit, as I exited at the opening of the "long" candle. Gotta be quick at this game, it seems!  
The last trade was straightforward, and yielded 14 pips profit.  
All profits quoted after the spread was taken away, leaving a total of 53 pips, which I'd rate as pretty good, seeing as it only took around an hour and three quarters to achieve.  
I'd say it's a pretty good method if you have the time to sit and wait for each opportunity to come along. However, it doesn't suit everyone, but I have to say I enjoyed the experience. If nothing else, I've proved to myself that it can be done, which improves one's confidence no end.

Hello,  
  
while backtesting CF to train my eye, I noticed many times the situation showed on screenshots I took from the backtesting platform.  
When Im analyzing offline chart I can see many CF entry points i.e. a pullback to 24ema. Notice the perfect alignment of all three shorter emas.  
  
[http://www.cntrade.cz/files/forex/co...r/eurusd_a.gif](http://www.cntrade.cz/files/forex/cornflower/eurusd_a.gif)  
[offline chart analyse showing the CornFlower entry point as I understand it]  
  
But in the real-time at the moment when the price is pulling back to the 24ema, the ema is almost always flat at the most recent candle or two and the 8 and 12 emas are almost always pointing the opposite direction. Also an intersection of a candle and 24ema often never occures in real-time, because the moving average is following the price movement and is also pulling back a little.  
  
[http://www.cntrade.cz/files/forex/co...r/eurusd_b.gif](http://www.cntrade.cz/files/forex/cornflower/eurusd_b.gif)  
[backtest situation showing the same CornFlower entry point at the moment of pullback]  
  
By ignoring this fact and focusing on the direction of the 8, 12 and 24 emas of previous 3-4 candles I was able to take the profit consistently.  
  
pta.

Hi All,  
I read this thread everyday and I too thought like JoshDance when I got into trading. BUT, after running across LEVER70's Trade Rules, (author of this sytem and thread) it really opened my eyes to componding. Don't get me wrong, if I am in a trade and it's running like a scared jack rabbit, I'm not getting out till it pivots.   
  
I would like to share One rule from Felicia's rule book:  
  
****RULE: Always stick to a small daily profit target**   
  
**Again, small daily wins are the key to success. This may be the second most important rule after rule #1. The chain of events that justify this rule generally follows this chronological pattern: 

  1. 1\. After a string of losses, you calm down, screw you head back on, and finally start to see the market clearly. You make one or two trades and meet your daily target.
  2. 2\. Relieved that you have been able to do this, you start to see good trades regularly. You take some of these trades for wins, and you realize that your target is well within your reach, several times a day.
  3. 3\. At this point, trading starts to seem easy and you are making money left and right. Overconfidence and greed sets in. Long before this happens, you may have already been overtrading.
  4. 4\. You begin to lose and eventually give back all of your profits.

At this point, one of two things happens:   
  

  1. You stop trading and assess what happened (which is, in fact, what led this author to write this rulebook). Having calmed yourself down, eaten a nice meal, etc., you return to step one above. You finish the week in profit, only to realize that _you would have_ _made the same amount of money all along if you had only stuck to your small daily target!_ Think about the time that you could have spent doing other things!
  2. You get desperate and lose even more money, so much that you are FORCED to stop and assess what happened. If you are a beginning trader, that this will happen at least once. In fact, it will probably happen multiple times. Ah, you say "oh, not me!" Yes, _you too_.

If you end up making the same money overtrading as you do when trading minimally for a small profit target, why overtrade? If we always acted with our heads, this question would never arise. The compounding that can be realized by fulfilling and sticking to a small daily target is mind-boggling.   
  
For example, let’s say you have $2,000 in your account. You resolve not to lose either 5% of your equity or 20 pips on every single trade that you make. In other words, a 20 pip loss would mean a decrease in equity of 5%. And this would be a worst-case scenario; ideally you would exit much earlier. To size your position, you would first divide your account size by the risk percentage (.05) to get the capital amount to be risked. Then you take that number and divide it by the maximum pip loss. The result, which you always round down to a whole number, is the dollar amount per pip that you are allowed to trade, regardless of the leverage offered by your broker.   
  
To illustrate: $2,000 * .05 = $100 / 20 = $5 per pip. $5 per pip means that you can trade 5 mini-lots. Only a mini account will give you the flexibility to trade the exact number of lots appropriate to your account size, and some brokers are less flexible than others. Now, for the compounding realized by fulfilling a 5 pip daily target: 

  1. After two months of trading (40 days), your original $2,000 has become $3,170. At this point, you are now trading $7 lots.
  2. After six months, you account is now worth $9,300, more than 4 times its original size. You are trading $24 lots.
  3. After a year, you have $46,945 to trade with. Your account has increased twentyfold, and you are trading $114 lots.
  4. After 18 months, your account is up to $233,035. You are trading $568 lots. Holy crap!

Now, you will have had to pay taxes once by this point, decreasing the overall amount. But you get the picture. After a mere 18 months, you have earned enough money to quit your job and live off your trading income.   
  
The high leverage offered to forex traders is what makes this kind of compounding possible. In no other market can you trade for this little, yet walk away with so much. What’s more, if your greed gets the best of you and you screw it all up (which I have done), it does not take all that much time to recover your losses. This is why forex is the best market for the small trader, as opposed to equities or even futures, where the leverage is much less. Keep your goals realistic, _stay disciplined_ , and financial freedom is within your grasp.   
  
Something to think about!!  
  
MG

Most people who post their trade results in this forum do so with the intent of sharing the experience to help others,and learn from others, like yourself. Sometimes they share a bad trade in order to get feed back on what they did wrong and how to correct the errors made. Other times they share good trades which resulted in a goodly number of pips being banked.   
  
I look to learn from others results both positive and negative and their methods. If someone has banked 70 plus pips on a trade,...I want to know how they did it. If it is a setup I am not familiar with, then I want to examine it and see if integrating a system might better my trading style.  
  
I started trading commodities part time in 2001, but I never really enjoyed trading in that venue. When I discovered forex in 2003, I switched and went full time in the Forex market in late 2004. My philosophy has always been to take small profits and when able increase the amount of lots traded. (Slow but steady.)   
  
I have been following this thread since Lever started it. I have back tested it, then and forward tested it until I was satisfied it fit my style of trading. Once I have decided which currency pair to trade for the day, I use the four TF Cornflower system to decide when to enter the trade.  
  
I live on the West Coast of the U.S. and trade both the Asian and London sessions. This morning during the London session, I determined that the GBP/JPY was going to continue on it's South bound journey. Using Cornflower I placed a sell at 236.72. The run started to end at 236.20. By the time I decided it was ending, I closed with a profit of 40 pips (my initial goal was only 20 pips.)   
  
Upon preparing to trade the Asian session this afternoon, I was surprised to find the GBP/JPY had dropped to 234.12. While I was happy with the 40 pip profit from the earlier trade, my first thought was, is there anything I could have done to have banked some of the 220 pips I left on the table. After careful thought (and several cups of coffee) I saw where I could improve my results.  
  
**Firstly** , when I closed the trade, it was quite apparent that price had begun an upward climb on the 5M chart. Instead of closing the trade, I should have noticed my option to use my trading station's close and reverse option and banked some of the pips on the retracement (it finally topped out at 237.14.)   
  
**Second** , I had focused my attention on the 5M chart ONLY (a habit left over from my scalping days.) Because price was choppy on the 5M chart, I decided another trade would not be viable. If I had looked at the H, 30M, and 15M charts, I would have seen the trend was intact and my choppy 5M chart was only price taking a breather.   
  
**Third** , If I had looked at the other charts, I could have placed another sell order with a trailing stop and gone to bed secure in the knowledge that I had already banked pips for the day, and the trade was covered by the stop. An observation I will not miss again.  
  
I decided to share this trade not to boast of my 40 pip profit, but to share my mistakes in analyzing the charts. Hopefully it will prevent someone else from missing an opportunity like the one I missed today.  
  
The venerable Peter Bain has said trading the Forex Market is like going to war. It's you against the other guy, and he more than likely has more experience, is better informed,....and wants your lunch! I am happy I banked those 40 pips and that my errors in evaluating the market only cost me unrealized profits (for those interested, I now trade 25 lots at $.84 per lot, or approximately $21.00 per pip) and not the hard earned money in the trading account.   
  
Trading the Forex is a great business. However, it is terribly unforgiving of any ignorance, carelessness or neglect, (the same mantra I have when I fly an aircraft). Learning from other people's mistakes and successes will help to shorten the learning curve.   
  
While the object of trading is to make money,....It's not how much money you make,....but what you do with the money after you make it that counts. Family, Passion, and Live Well.  
  
Clansman

Felicia, a million pips to you for your insights that you have so generously shared! Not only is Cornflower one of the most astute observations about the workings of the forex marketplace, but your Rules for trading are simply astounding. You have given us all a most powerful tool for trading with Cornflower. Yes, one must be aware of Support, Resistance and the Weekly Trendline, but Cornflower is where it's at! I look forward to the continued insights and additions that will continue to be added to this thread as the year goes on.  
  
One thing I've noticed and may be of help is that there are many occasions where you look at the hourly and it's trending so fast that there isn't the slightest hint of a pullback to even the 8 EMA. You then drop to the 30M chart and again, no pullbacks. Not only are there no pullbacks, but there's DISTANCE between the high or low of the bar and the 8 EMA. Drop to the 15M and it's still a runaway Piptrain. No pullbacks in sight, how to take advantage of this moneymaker? Well, I've found that in these times there is no reason to not be making money in an obvious market move. Just drop down to the 5M and 1M charts in those circumstances and play those timeframes Cornflower style exactly the same as if they were the 1H chart. What I'm saying is that there is always a timeframe to play Cornflower on in a trending market. Just find the one that has shown a couple pullbacks to the 12/24 area and then wait for the next opportunity to get in. You have to keep a vigilant eye on your stops, as always, but as long as you do, you've got an 80% chance of winning which is HUGE.  
  
Hope this helps. Let me know if I wasn't clear...

Thanks Matrixxdg.   
  
I understand, it is especially frustrating when your stop is hit and price then turns around and proceeds to move another 20 to 30 pips before finally stalling out. I prefer to keep my stop line in my head while I am trading (I find it allows for more flexibility when price starts to fluctuate.) If there is a strong trend and price is moving well, I keep a 30 pip margin in my head. If it is ranging, I use 20 pips on either side of the channel. I follow the 5M and 15M charts when it is ranging. I use pivot points and support and resistance lines, and I watch carefully around those areas (it is amazing how often a Cornflower pullback happens around those areas.)  
  
If I have a trade that is in the positive and I am going to be away from the computer, I set my stop half way between where price is and my break even point, assuring some profit. When I use a trailing stop, I set it anywhere between 30 pips and 100 pips behind price (depends on the particular currency and the movement at the time.) If I am sure price will continue on a trend, but I can't gauge where it might retrace to before continuing, I will set a higher trailing stop. Unfortunately, trading is part art and part science....more art than science.  
  
I hope the above is useful.  
  
BTW,....I am MacGregor as well!!!  
  
Clansman

I tried a couple of scalps today on Cable, and I thought I'd show you how I avoided what could have been a bad trade. Pretty basic stuff, but then there's a lot of new people coming on all the time, isn't there?  
I got in for a nice scalp of 26 pips where you can see the labels. I exited this trade sharpish after the long lower shadow gave an indication that the bears where fighting back. Sure enough, the price started rising rapidly, and I was waiting for it to stall at any of the MA lines. In the meantime, I drew a trend line from the first black arrow to see if it would prove to show resistance to the rising price. Obviously, it didn't, and the price didn't stop until it hit the 50sma. Now, of course, my trend line had the potential to be a support, so I waited to see what would happen. I watched the price drop through 3 MA's until it came to a grinding halt at my trend line, where the second black arrow is pointing. The next candlestick proved to be a hammer, just above the M1 line indicating a reversal and so it proved. A simple trend line saved me a lot of grief. Magic, eh?![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)

Spot on, mate, and congrats on your other trades. You're cottoning on fast! One of the main reasons I like the Cornflower is that there's no indicators, other than MA's, plus I like to use Pivot Points and Trend lines. The MA's give you direction AND support/resistance. I'm never without pivots on my charts, as they give you targets and again, support/resistance. Trend lines complete the set as far as I'm concerned, keeping you in good trades and preventing you entering bad trades. Indicators have their place, but not in Cornflower. It's been proved time and time again how good it is WITHOUT indicators, so why buck the trend? ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)

Hey Bunton,......Eight for eight!! That's a good week my friend! When I started trading the Forex, I only did four to five trades per week.   
  
The biggest problem for me when I switched from commodities to the forex venue was the perceived speed of the live charts (I had traded commodities using paper charts and called the broker once a week to place my trades.) If the 5M charts are giving you a little trouble, switch to 1M charts and observe them for awhile. When you switch back to the 5M for trading, they will seem slower and will appear clearer to your eye.  
  
Don't worry about the 100 pip moves at this time. You banked the profit from eight trades! As your trading account grows, you will be able to increase the number of lots you trade. Imagine the profit if you had been able to make those same trades with twice the number of lots. Slow and steady will increase the account (and the number of lots you trade.) Before you know it, you will be able to go full time and kick the day job (if you like.) I started with 1 lot per trade. Over a period of time, I increased the number of lots to 25 per trade.   
  
The Cornflower system is one of the best I have seen. It does a fantastic job of showing a trader when to enter and exit a trade (I have thanked Lever both in this forum and in PM's for sharing the Cornflower system.) Keep your discipline and don't force the trades and you will be successful in this business.  
  
Trade well.

In forex trading like everything else, you have to pay your dues (sometimes quite literally if you are not careful.) I crashed my first forex account and did serious damage to the second before I developed the style that worked for me.  
  
While I can't tell you what will work for you,....I can share what I did on my road to surviving the forex market.  
  
My first goal was to be consistent in my trading (seven successful trades out of ten was my goal.) Next I had to decide how much risk I was willing to live with, as well as, a nonemotional, mechanical, way to increase the number of lots in my trades. I did that by setting up an excel spread sheet with the following headings; # Lots, Stop pips, Margin, Total Margin Required, Trade Profit, Draw, To Account, Balance. Once the formulas are tied in, you can see the potential risk for your trades. There are only three places you can make changes in the formulas, Beginning Balance, # Lots, and Draw. All columns with the exception of the # Lots column (which is a straight number) are in dollars . I'll dig up an example and post it soon.  
  
When a change is made in the the # Lots column, all columns with the exception of the Draw column are changed.  
  
The Total Margin Required column is the combined total of the Stop Pips and Margin columns.  
  
The Stop Pips column is the number of pips your stop is set to in dollars. It is the most important in my mind. It tells you in dollars how much you will be risking for the number of lots you want to trade. I prefer to look at dollars vs percentages when evaluating my risk (i.e. $1,000.00 is more sobering to me than say 2%.) I also use my balance in determining the number of lots to trade. The spread sheet holds forty-four trades with increasing lots as you move down the page. If I experience a loss, I look to the balance on the spread sheet that is the closest amount below my actual account and place my next trade using the # of lots indicated.  
  
The draw column is the amount you pull from the account to pay yourself.   
  
I have one sheet for the EUR/USD and GBP/USD (since those currencies are in even dollars) and one for GBP/JPY, USD/CHF, USD/JPY, which are approximately $0.85 per pip.  
  
I decided to setup a corporation for my trading account. Some people had said to me that a corporation is a lot of extra paper work for just one person. However, I preferred the benefits of a corporation. The corporation pays me biweekly and takes my taxes out of my check just like any other paycheck. The company has different tax advantages than I do as an individual. The most important reason in my mind, for setting up a corporation is....it's cleaner. Everything is documented and above board.   
  
If my ramblings have not answered your question,..I hope they have at least pointed you to the road best suited to you.  
  
Trade well...live well.

When the 8/12/24ema's are stacked under the 72ema you are in a downtrend. When they are stacked over the 72ema you are in an uptrend.  
On some of the TF's, I will draw a Tom DeMark trend line to confirm the trend. I also check the Daily long term trend.

Here is an example as I interrupt the CF. we have USD/CAD it flagged a buy signal (aggressive) off the chart on the left. Now if you did not buy off the 30min chart you do nothing. The 1hr chart still does not have the proper EMA’s set up. Once the 24ema gets above the 72ema we now have a qualified uptrend and one can look to get long on a pullback. As for exact place to do so is up to the trader. So I think yes this system is discretionary. You decide if and when you get in based off the latest info you have on your charts. Can it be set up mechanically? Not sure as I would not do it.

Hello mate, and first of all, well done for actually having the nerve to admit to all and sundry that you've been through this thread 3 times yet the method still mystifies you. A lot of newbies out there wouldn't have had the balls to do that, mate, quite honestly, and they'd have moved on to something else by now. So give yourself a pat on the back! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)   
  
As for the method itself......the best thing about Cornflower is that, once you understand the simple rules, you can adapt it to your own way of trading. It's so versatile, I kid you not. The original rules basically say to trade pull-backs on the 1H charts and break-outs on the 30m charts, which gives you a good start. You can trade pull-backs after price has touched 24ema, 12ema or 8ema, depending on how fast and strong the trend is. A strong trend often gives the price no time to retrace to the 12ema, never mind the 24ema, before it's off again on its travels. So at time likes that, you have to be really on the ball to spot a pull-back to the 8ema. However, when the trade is a bit more pedestrian, then a nice pull-back to the 12 or the 24 is just the ticket to prepare you for entering what could be a nice trade.  
  
On the 30min chart, watch for what looks like a trend change. The 8, 12 and 24, will all show signs of reversing, and when they do and cross the 72, that's your break-out, and a clear opportunity for a nice long or short trade, depending on direction.  
  
I know that Felicia doesn't recommend this, but you CAN do all this on the 15min charts as well, but if she doesn't recommend it, then you can be sure that there's a good reason. However, by her own admission, it CAN be scalped on the 5min and the 1min charts, and I've proved that to myself just lately by joining in the action. Fast and furious, but a lot of fun! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)   
  
Anyway, mate, just thought I'd offer you my own view on all this, but in the end, it's down to you and you alone how you handle it. It's a great system.....stick with it, adapt to it, and you'll never regret it, I promise.  
  
Nevertheless, PLEASE read the pdf we've all been on about. It's an artform in itself! Also, try and study as many charts as possible that people have posted, and try working out WHY they did what they did. Best of luck, mate.  
  
Cheers

Hello again, mate.  
My thoughts on this one is that it's always best to wait to see what the next candle is going to do. You may get the price heading towards the 12 or the 24ema and sometimes it'll come to a grinding halt right on the MA, with the next candle showing signs of a definite reversal, which is what you want. Other times, the next candle could carry merrily on in the same direction, crossing towards the 72ema. At times like that, you have to wait for the price to come back across the 24ema before entering the trade. Of course, nothing is guaranteed, but if it's gone into the 24-72 zone and reversed, then it's starting to look likely that it's going to provide a nice little trade.  
  
Really, it's all about one's own judgement. Watch the candles and try and read what they're tellling you. With the Cornflower system, you don't need any indicators other than the candles, the MA's and (for me, at least) pivot points, with the odd trend line thrown in now and again. Pivot points stop me from entering trades with bad Risk/Reward Ratios, but at the same time, give me clear targets to work towards.  
  
Works for me, mate, and it'll work for you, once you've got a routine established.  
  
Cheers

Hello mate.  
It looks as if you're getting there. However, just a couple of comments. Waiting for the next candle to close is up to you, mate. Some do and some don't. It's purely a matter of choice. The purists will tell you that waiting is the correct thing to do, but others will say no, get on board ASAP! My advice is to judge each case on its merits, and act accordingly. If the signals all look right to you, and you're feeling confident about the trade, then go for it. Otherwise, stay out and watch, entering only when you feel at ease with your decision. What is right or wrong to YOU is the only thing that matters when it comes right down to it.  
Your end comments regarding using smaller TF's to pin-point entries is spot on. You're further along than you think, mate! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)   
I'd like to suggest that you study all the charts you can get hold of, mate, so you can see where other people succeeded or failed. Go back to the "Trading Systems" page, scroll down to where "Cornflower 1hr method" is, and you'll see a little paper-clip. Click on that, and a new window will open with all the attachments that people have submitted since the thread began. LOADS of charts, I promise you! Study them and learn.  
  
Take care, mate, and keep on keepin' on.

Thanks Eyevoltage.  
  
When I redid my daily pivots and analysis for this session, I noticed the main trend on the Daily chart was down with a smaller upward trend (possible Bear flag) and I had Histogram divergence, coupled with this pair coming off its lowest price in one year. The Hourly chart had an up trend with MACD, price, and ema's pointed up, along with a pull back to the 8ema. On the 15M chart, the trend was up while price was flat on the M3. The 8 and 12 ema's were pointed down and I had a spinning top on the 24ema.  
  
Price moved down from my M3 to half way between my M3 and CPP. It then reversed and headed for the M3 where it stayed for awhile. I waited to enter until price had convincingly penetrated the M3. The ema's on the Hourly, 30M, 15M, and the 5M were also headed up (the 5M was not as clean as I would have liked, but it wasn't that much of a negative.)  
  
When it did start moving, price went through my R1 and banged up against my M4. I moved the trailing stop by hand as I went (I wanted to keep as much as possible.) In hindsight, I should have probably closed the trade when it hit the M4. Price action was running out of momentum. Closing at the M4 would have given a profit of 170 pips. But hey......hindsight is 20/20, and I'm happy with the 120 pips.

Hello Apume,  
  
Out of respect for Lever, I am a bit hesitant to discuss other trading ideas on the Cornflower thread. That being said, I believe I can state how I blend the Cornflower system into my trading psyche.   
  
First I would recommend you read the following threads here on the forum;  
Jacko's Forex house of pleasure and pain. The first page really gives you his system in a nutshell, however I highly recommend reading the entire thread.   
Second read Phillip Nel's 5Min Intraday System.  
  
How I trade. When I am deciding which pairs to trade, I put up three charts; Daily, Hourly, and 15M. Each chart has the four Cornflower ema's 8,12,24, and 72 (weighted more heavily towards the most recent price action.) I also have a MACD with the standard default settings of 12,26,9. Before we go any farther, Let me make one thing clear about the MACD...**I use the MACD for divergence only. It is a lagging indicator and cannot be used to make entry decisions.** OK,....now that I have that out of the way, here's how I analyze the charts. I start with the Daily. First I look at the trend and the Cornflower trend to see the long term direction. Next I look for divergence between price action and MACD, and the Histogram. Divergence in the MACD or its Histogram may indicate a new direction for price. I also look to see if there are any telltale candle patterns such as a new high or low, double top or bottom, head and shoulders, triangle, etc.. After finishing the Daily, I move to the Hourly chart. I then go through the same procedure I did on the Daily chart. After finishing the Hourly chart, I move to the 15M chart. I do the same on the 15M chart as I did on the Daily and the Hourly charts. However, I also take into consideration where price is in relation to my pivot points on the 15M chart. I do this with all the pairs I follow. When I am watching for a trade opportunity, I watch the 5M and 15M charts, since a retracement will start with the lower TF charts. Once I see a retracement starting on the 5M and 15M charts, I then begin paying more attention to the 30M chart. Depending on how it looks, I will either trade off the 30M chart or wait for the retracement on the Hourly chart. Once you develop the feel for the Cornflower system, I believe you will find it to be a very solid trading system.  
  
While I cannot tell you what will work for you, I hope the above is useful in your search for your own way. One last thing,....trading the Forex is part art, part science,........and its more art than science.  
  
Good luck on your learning curve,...may it be swift and profitable.

Hey Bunton,  
  
I use the Cornflower 8,12,24,and 72 ema's on my 5M chart. Retracements start to happen on the lower time frame charts. I use the 15M charts for trade entries and exits (less whipsaws.) I use the 5M charts to clarify any rapid price action on the 15M charts. One of the things I look for is a consistency of the ema's between the Hourly, 30M, 15M, and 5M charts. I also use my pivot points to see where price is on the charts (pivot points are like working with a topo map...it lets you see the terrain in advance.)  
  
Hope that helps.

I live on the West Coast as well. I trade the Asian and London sessions. Tokyo opens at 1600 PT and London at 0000 PT. The Asian session is not as volatile as the London session. There is action around the London session opening most days (usually around 2300 PT to 0100 PT.) Another active time is between 0500 PT and 0900 PT.

This system doesn't react to EMA crosses. It reacts to price action in relation to EMAs and uses EMA position to dictate trend. While it's true that short EMAs crossing up through the 72 EMA would signal the beginning of an uptrend, nothing is done unless price action confirms a bullish move (i.e. a strong bull candle on the 30 min chart piercing the 72 EMA with the other EMAs above the 72 EMA would be an aggressive buy signal)

As I interpret it, there is no "indicator" that encompasses this system. In fact, this system is an indicator free system that is controlled by price action and trend, with all signals being based on price action alone. I have no idea what the "signal line indicator" is, so I could be wrong, but you really don't need an indicator to make this system work for you.  
  
If you're still not getting this, I suggest you reread the posts again... slowly... (especially the ones written by Felicia) because I think they are VERY clearly written.  
  
That aside, I'd like to thank Felicia for reintroducing me to a slightly more "purist" method of trading. It's been years since I've started trading and somewhere along the way, I found a path that led me away from my "purist" trading methods and started relying on indicators to make decisions for me. After finding this thread, I've regained my interest in watching price bars and am going back to my old ways. Cheers!

Hi fx_ninja. The nature of the system requires that the EMAs be on the price graph. How would you know the price has pulled back to the 12ema if the EMAs are on a separate window? Sure, a separate window would show the trend, but you wouldn't know where to enter.   
  
The best advice for trading Cornflower is **Patience**. One of the people in my chatroom sometimes doesn't take a CF trade for days, just waiting for the perfect setup, then he goes and takes several hundred pips in one go at the end of the week, then goes off grinning like a Cheshire Cat to count his money.   
  
This week it was the jpy pairs. Friday was a bit of a CF goldmine. I took 225 pips myself on u/j, e/j and g/j. I could have got more, but I wasn't quick enough to grab entries on the other jpy pairs. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
To maximise profit is simple. Just wait for the properly stacked EMAs at 30-60 degrees to show up, then just trade the pullbacks.

I know this may cause more false positives, but I'm looking for long runners of 100+ before I jump the gun and close it out. Hi All,  
  
I have been using the cornflower for awhile and doing very well. I have the ability to trade during the day and was looking for a Intraday type style.   
  
Well here is what I have been using for the past 2 weeks with great success and thought I would share.  
  
I am using the cornflower setup on a 10 minute chart with the following criteria:  
  
Set up a 10M chart with the Cornflower EMA’s   
  
On your chart, set an alert to signal when the 24 ema crosses the 8 ema AND a second alert when the 8 ema crosses the 72 ema. This covers all of your bases.  
  
For a successful trade, make sure the 8, 12, 24 ema’s are moving in the direction of the move with about a 20% angle or more. The more aggressive the angle of the ema’s the better the possibility of a successful trade and no reversal.  
  
Also, the candle has to be moving UP or DOWN aggressively. The crossing of the 8ema and the 24ema will happen almost immediately at the beginning of the new move.  
  
I ride the move until I see the first close of a red candle on the BUY or a green candle on the SELL, then I get out. Or, I use the RENKO chart to determine when the move has stopped.(Not allot of charting packages have RENKO, mine does, and I love it)  
  
  
I know this is not how cornflower was originally designed by Lever70, but it's working for me for intraday trading.

bullrock,  
  
After using the 4H TF charts with your ema settings side-by-side with mine, it became painfully obvious that my settings were to close together (gave me a headache looking at the chart.)  
  
In my early days, I used a half dozen indicators (instead of price action and trend) to make my trading decisions. I eventually settled on using the MACD (for divergence and histogram divergence) and an MA or two.   
  
I used two MACD settings for this chart. The first is 12/100/9 from TKimble's thread "12_100_9 Trending System." For the second, I used 5/13/1 from cornelius2's thread "Trading in 8 pairs." Laying the 5/13/1 over the 12/100/9 allows me to pick up the histogram divergence quickly. What I didn't expect was the 12/100/9 to cross before the 10ema crossed the 15ema (it does it on all currency pairs I follow.) I realize the MACD is not part of the Cornflower system, however, I use the divergence to help plan my entries and exits along with pivot points.  
  
I would like to hear your thoughts on this.  
  
Regards,  
Clansman

Looking at these EMA values, it seems that the pullbacks are not as deep or predictable, so it may be difficult to pinpoint exactly where to enter. If you look back in time, you will see that these pairs will go a considerable distance against you before netting delicious profits. And also, when trading longer timeframes, you must absolutely hold for the gains of several hundred pips. Otherwise you can't make up for the big losses. Patience pays.

Of all the indicators out there, the MACD is closest to price because it is a function of the distance between moving averages. My beef with it is its tendency to lag price action. However, Alexander Elder has made a good case for the power of MACD divergences on longer-term charts. Though I am averse to indicators, if something shows promise I will not dismiss it out of hand.  
  
Phillip Nel has a very nice 4H system based on the 5-13-1 MACD. I suggest reading up on it. There might be a way to combine his insights with Cornflower into something that is tradeable. However, I am not sure what you're doing with the other MACD. It appears to mimic the action of the shorter moving averages on the chart.

That is exactly what it means. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)   
  
The best trends are indicated by a nice liftoff or descent of the short EMAs from the 72 EMA. If the angle of separation is not clearly visible, then we have stagnant price action, and a lower-probability setup. I do not take trades unless the short EMAs have clearly separated from the 72 EMA. When we get the inevitable pullback, we should have a clearly identifiable trend in place. These are the only conditions under which we should take a CF trade. NOT when the short EMAs have yet to cross over the 72 EMA, or when they have kinda sorta crossed. Don't guess and don't force trades. Wait for the best entries.

Thanks bunton. It's not too often I get a trade that runs that long. It sure feels good when they do.  
  
MACD stands for Moving Average Convergence / Divergence. It shows the difference between a fast and slow ema (set to close.) It also has an ema which is the signal line. The standard settings are 12 (fast ema,) 26 (slow ema.) and 9 (signal line.) Another component is the histogram. It is there to help show when the MACD and signal lines are crossing.   
  
MACD is designed to show trend changes, however, it is really too slow to be used in forex trading. I use it for divergence and histogram divergence. For example, divergence happens when price action makes a new high and MACD is heading the other direction. This indicates that there is the possibility that the upward trend is slowing down and maybe turning.  
  
I posted a link for Answers.com. Click on the link and type MACD in the search window, and it will give you more detailed information.  
  
<http://www.answers.com/>  
  
  
Regards,

I guess we are all too busy making money ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)  
  
In reality, the system needs no additions to work. All you need to do is develop the patience, and the willpower to trade only strong setups and avoid the weak ones or making trades, just to be in the market.  
  
In recent weeks, I have discovered 2 nice pairs to trade CF with.  
  
First is GBP/NZD. Despite the usually horrendous spread of around 30-35 pips at most brokers that even carry this pair, the results can be enormous.  
  
Use a 100pip stop, targets 300-500 pips, move stop to break even at +70-+80, trail 120pips or greater. This is a fantastic pair to trade and in my opinion, the only way to trade NZD.  
  
The second pair is GBP/CAD. With a much nicer spread of 10 pips, this one can also pick up a great number of pips. Also, with CAD being such a nice trending currency, you can pick up long runs using Cornflower. Anywhere from 100-300 pips per day is possible with this pair.  
  
Try both pairs on demo for a couple of weeks to get a feel for them. I think you will agree they are quite remarkable.

Hey Quickdraw.  
In answer to your scalping question, I have been watching and demo-ing both 1m and 5m charts with Cornflower and found them to be very much "do-able"! ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)   
  
The MA's are different from the longer TF's, but I have found that they lend themselves very nicely to scalping. Felicia, by her own admission, likes scalping, but says that Cornflower is intended primarily to be used with the 30m chart (trading breakouts), and the 1H chart (trading pull-backs). At least, that's how I've interpreted her instructions.  
  
To be honest, I've been using both the above ways of trading on the 1m and the 5m charts, usually aiming for around 10 pips at a time, or aiming for the next Pivot line. As with most trading, it's not just taking any trade that comes along, but watching for what could be identified as a high-probability trades. In other words, stick to the basic Cornflower rules, even on these smaller TF's and you'll soon spot the opportunities if you have the patience. These results, by the way, are from trading Cable, as I've found it to be ideal for this type of trading. Even on a quiet day, Cable usually supplies some nice scalping trades.  
  
Anyway, the only way you're going to find out if it's for you, is to jump in and try it, mate. Best of luck.  
  
Cheers

Hello everyone,  
  
I have been reading this thread for a while, and trading this method. I also use phil neal?? macd signal to help me filter good trades from bad. I just did 65 pips from cad/jpy and 45 pips from usd/cad, the news just accelerated the move!   
  
i usually place a few trades after noram close, once things settle down, but beware of placing jpy nzd pairs as i often find u get big position trade movements to knock out your stops, just hold onto your buttocks sometimes!!! Most of my trading is when i get up GMT. I hit my pip target, then off i go to live. If the wife wants a new sofa, i will trade the extra few pips till i get that. Mostly, I compund my account, only taking very little from it. Remember, its not how many pips you get, its the pips value.  
  
I trade for a living so am able to watch my screens throughout the day, thus i dont put limits on, and usually stops of no more than 50. if you get hit on a 50 stop, your either braindead or very unlucky. i use the cornflower method as prescribed by our leader, the hon. vagrant, on a 1 hour chart. i also use a macd (5.13.1). Enter a trade only if a) cornflower rules met, b) macd close higher/lower. Perfect long set up on a pullback is macd below 0.15 -0.30, curved with maybe 5 bars then a higher close, loads of pips as you catch the start of the move, not just a little pullback. Works perfectly with cornflower. For a riskier trade, look for a slight pullback as per cornflower and a continuation on macd, not as many pips but better than a kick in the balls.  
  
Anyway, just did another 30 pips on eur/usd, oh, life is sweet xxx

Nobody can be told what The Matrix is. You'll have to see it yourself.

Hi Joe, I use good old s/r to determine when to jump off. Also, when MACD goes neutral (ie 0 line), its usually a good time to get off as price quite often changes direction or stalls, unless there are no barriers in the way of further price trend continuation. A lower/higher close on the smaller time frames builds up to a lower/higher close on the higher time frames, so discretion is paramount. I use good money management ie, 90% of good money management is getting in the trade at the right time, so my stops are quite tight. TP when the move runs out of steam.  
  
I do use mt4 for charting, so will post asap.  
  
good luck, shinny

Yes, it was (unbelievably) a real account. So you can imagine the pain I felt when it went from $17 to $10. In less than half the time it took me to get from $8 to $17.  
  
My point is, stick to what works and don't change the system. Like what Lever70 said somewhere ... if you took the right trade, it goes your way almost immediately. A little trick I had was to take half my bets off the table if/when the trade goes my way within the first 30 mins to 1 hour, and let the other half of my position ride. If prices came back down I may enter with another full position and do the same thing ... take half off if the trade goes my way within the first 30 mins to 1 hour.  
  
I'm not even sure if this makes sense but to me it sure did, and that's what I'm going to do after I take a few days break off trading. It sure stinks to make 100% return and only to lose 50% to get back to where you were before.  
  
Oh, and another mistake I made was when I attempted to modify this system or use another system to trade, I even doubled my position sizes. Big mistake, too early for that.  
  
Thanks lever70 for sharing your ideas.

I've been looking throughout this thread for various examples of using multiple time frames in our decision to enter a trade (such as the above example). It seems like a really good idea, but the problem is that when the multiple time frames are aligned, will the price have move up too much to be touching the 12 or 24 ema? Therefore it seems that we would rarely - if ever - will be able to enter a true CF trade.   
  
If, for example on a buy trade, the time frames are aligned and the price dips back down to the 12 or 24 ema, then wouldn't at least 1 or more of the time frames be pointing downward and be out of alignment? By using the idea of trading when multiple time frames are aligned, then we would not be able to take the trade if it dips back to touch the 12 or 24 ema. I've see here on this thread to wait until the time frames are aligned and then enter when the 5 min chart is pointing upwards (as in a buy trade). However, at that point when the 5 min chart is pointing upwards then it most likely is not touching the 12 or 24 ema anymore. Isn't that true?   
  
It's a "Catch-22" situation. We'd like to buy when the various multiple time frames are pointing upward, but when they are pointing upward then that most likely means the price has already moved up and away from the 12 and 24 ema. Do you guys see the dilemma?

Well I've gone through data on the gbp/usd from 1/1/01 to 1/1/03 so far.....2 years!  
  
I wont bother posting any specific details since being a manual backtest my results will differ significantly from what someone else may get. Further to that, I believe that with practice and more experience the results would be even better than what I achieved.  
  
Suffice to say I have found this system to be very solid. A high % win rate and with proper MM will generate good returns.  
  
The only thing I think worth mentioning is to beware when the market is ranging. I did find a period where I had a number of losing trades in a row. Far more than any other period. Upon closer inspection I realised the 4 hour chart was showing a ranging market for the entire period. Having said that, it still would have been a profitable period had I been more diligent in closing out any trade that had gone at least 15 pips into profit before turning around for a loss. I forgot about that tip a few times during my testing.  
  
Once again thanks to Lever70 for sharing this great idea.  
  
Cheers,  
PKFFW

I only post when I have something to say (though I check the thread daily.)   
  
I trade for a living, and I incorporated Cornflower into my trading methodology because it is a solid dependable system. The few losses I have had using the system are due to my interpretation of the charts, or to paraphrase Shakespeare, the fault dear traders is not in our charts, but in ourselves (yeah I know,...I'm going to English lit hell for that.)  
  
The real beauty of Cornflower is it is simple to understand. I am using it to teach my three youngest children (8, 10, and 12 years old) how to trade. The older four are already out, and on with their careers and currently not interested in the markets.   
  
Each one of the children has a demo account and when they become proficient trading on the demos, I will open a $300.00 mini account for each child. The rules are simple. At the end of each month, 50% of the profit goes into a savings account (to be rolled into a Roth IRA when large enough to do so) 25% is theirs to spend as they like, and the last 25% stays in the account (in order to increase the number of lots per trade.) If they make bad trades and lose the account, a portion of their allowance will be held back to rebuild the account.  
  
Watching the children working with Cornflower has been an enlightening experience. They follow the rules and wait for the pull back to trade (they misread the charts at times, however, they are getting better with experience.) They do not try to push the trade or jump early. They just follow the rules...The way we all do,....right?

People like to think that they are smart and have made a discovery that will change the world. This is why 99% of Forex traders are simply losers.   
Trading is not about finding the ultimate system that makes you heaps of cash. It is about being married to a boring screen day in day out making sure you are as strict as a catholic monk. Following your lame plan to the letter.  
  
Then and only then will you make money. The smart ones get as far away from trading whenever they can and simply get it out of the way. Their a hundreds of systems that work out there. Do the backtests. But when you go to trade them live they don't work. Why?  
  
Because they bore the pants off you! If you want to make money trading. Find a plan. Stick to it. Follow your trading plan to the letter. Stay away from Forums. They are full of losers that treat Trading more like playing poker machines than seriously making money. That's why they lose.  
  
Find a system you like. Write a plan that calculates how much you need to invest to make so much a week based on a backtest. Don't be surprised when you make money. Expect it. Follow your plan and instead of hanging out with losers in forums. Sell it. You'll have much more fun than trading. > [Quoting lever70](/thread/post/1441939#post1441939 "View Quoted Post")
> 
> Disliked
> 
> Good question. I would say the following:  
>    
>  1) Flattening EMAs are never a good sign. It means price action is stalling. You want a well-oiled Jaguar, not a Dodge Dart.  
>    
>  2) A chart whose EMAs fit the criteria, yet whose pattern is sloppy and ill-defined. You want nice, steady movement.  
>    
>  3) Long wicks all over the place. Wicks pointing against the direction of your trade is a good thing; it indicates that price successfully repelled an area of potential supply, with ample buyers stepping in. Long wicks in both directions means that the market is undecided as to what the price should be, so you have traders buying and selling and scalping and generally passing the crack pipe. Crack is wack.  
>    
>  4) A strong candle close that causes the 8 and 12 EMAs to point opposite the direction of your trade. Stay out.   
>    
>  5) Short EMAs stacked opposite to the direction of the 72 EMA. Stay out.
>

> Nice trade Clansman![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1) Can I ask where you placed your stop on that trade? I've been having a bit of trouble with my stops. I want to keep my risk/reward to at least 1:1, but I keep getting stopped out with the trade only to run on.
> 
> Ignored

I set my stops between 50 and 100 pips (depending on the currency.) That being said, if you have timed the entry correctly you should only see a reversal of 20 to 25 pips after entry. Once I am in profit I move my stops up to keep my profit. When moving stops the distance behind price is really dependent on the volatility of the currency at the time. If it looks like a trend is running out of steam, then I keep my stop close. If on the other hand the trend is strong, but whipsawing its way up (or down,) then I keep my stops farther out. Setting targets of 20 or 30 pips and collecting is a solid way to increase your trading account.   
  
Keeping a 1:1 risk/reward ratio is a good goal, however, it can also limit your profits. Now before everyone starts screaming, let me explain my thinking. If a trader consistently has 6 or 7 successful trades out of every 10 trades, he can with careful money management increase his account. For example, if a person sets his stops for 20 pips and his TP for 20 pips, his risk/reward is 1:1. Using the numbers from above we know we will hit the stop loss 3 or 4 times out of every 10. That equates to 60 to 80 pips lost. However, 6 to 7 successful trades equals 120 to 140 pips. This gives a profit over the 10 trades of 40 to 80 pips. Carefully increasing the number of lots as the account balance increases, will over a period of time develop the trader's income to the level he or she desires. Being consistent and disciplined in one's trading will in time lead to success. As I'm sure you have realized, it does not happen over night.  
  
I hope my ramblings have been of help.

I started with two currencies, the EUR/USD and the GBP/USD. After becoming familiar with their personalities, I then added the USD/CHF. I currently have eight currencies I am following. On my screen, I have eight 1H charts. When one (or more) of the charts shows a setup starting to take shape, I then switch to 30M charts, and down to the 15M and 5M when needed.  
  
If I am trading multiple currencies, I use less lots per trade than if I were trading only one currency.

I did trade the AUD/USD, but I did not enter until after 0300 ET. I waited to see which way price was going to head. I was looking at a double bottom at my M2 pivot point, histogram divergence suggesting a possible move up and price was also looking like a CF retracement was starting. To muddy the waters a little more, the Swiss Retail Sales numbers were coming out at 0315 ET. As you can see by the charts, price bounced off the 72 ema and my Central Pivot Point at approximately 0300. I watched the 5M chart and went short at 8967 after price penetrated my M2. At 8917, I decided to take the money and run.

Firstly I should say that I have only been trading this system for a couple of months and am still finding my way. I've been trading options full time for a couple of years, but now just trade FX using this system.  
I use the 5 minute set up to time my way in to the 1 hour cornflower.Setting a limit order at the 12 or 24 goes against the grain for me.I mightn't make as many pips, but I'd rather it was lined up on the 5 min. chart.  
I do scalp as well. I started off with a goal of 20 pips per day, and increasing my lots each week, providing I made at least 100 pips the week before. I've managed to do that. Last week was 211 pips.This week I'm up 110 so far.My revised goal is 250 a week. I aim to scalp less as I'm trading too many hours. I read the Cornflower draft every few days to remind me what I'm looking for.Today I've been testing entry with the 8/24 cross on the 15 min chart, in line with the 1 hr Cornflower for entry and am still testing whether I should use the 12/24 on 1 hr for exit or the 8/24 o 15 min. As this is a pullback system rather than a crossover I still wait for a pullback. I'd love to hear from anyone with thoughts on this. I've found (in my very limited testing) that quite a few times if I'd have waited for the 8/24 on 15 cross it is the same as a pullback on the 5minute entry without the stress. I'm rambling... Lack of sleep.Hope it helps.

Hi,  
  
Draw the date line (dotted vertical line) on your chart by right clicking on your chart and going to properties (bottom) and selecting "period separators". Also, google and search for "MT4 Market Hours indicator and add it to your chart, which will give you visual market hours for Asian, London and US sessions with colored horizontal bars.  
  
View the behavior of the pair of your interest over the past days in relation to the market hours or time of the day. You will then have a better assurance of the retrace for entries and also for exits.  
  
It's often pays if you enter when market gets active and that is usually the pre-open to few hours of each market session. Also note that trends often reverse in the afternoon. Further watch out for the market close and the time of the day/ day of the week for new entries.  
  
The above applies to any intra day trading method or strategy.  
  
My view on your down arrow is, it will likely to be a nice retrace for "long", but not for "short". It's a Friday close and you should wait until the market opens on Sunday afternoon and follow the move there on.<http://www.forexfactory.com/images/icons/icon7.gif>  
  
RS

Hi everyone - I'm the new guy ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44b.png?v=15.1)  
  
I've been a programmer since high school and this weekend decided to teach myself MQL4. The Cornflower system seemed like a good project to learn with due to its simplicity. I didn't see that anyone had posted an EA for it - if I've missed it, my apologies. Hopefully I'm not stepping on anyone's toes here.  
  
I hesitate to post the EA itself as it is still in its development stages. If anyone that has experience with MQL4 wants to see it, they're welcome to PM me for it. Backtesting shows some modestly successful gains over the past three months. These gains are all based on trades of one lot at a time.  
  
EURUSD - 753 pips  
AUDUSD - 721 pips  
USDCAD - 669 pips  
USDCHF - 254 pips  
  
These figures initially excited me, very much!! But further examination tells me it can be better ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1) Some notes:  
  
1) While the EA is profitable, profitable trades occur only about 50-60% of the time. Higher gains than losses compensate for this, however, I would like to refine the entry criteria. More to follow.  
  
2) I find that this EA works best with a currency that is strongly trending. Even moderate choppiness (is that a word?) shows more losing than winning trades. I added to the D1 chart EMA62, EMA200, and SMA800 (thanks Tiki) which improved this greatly. I hope that fixing the point above will also help this.  
  
Here's the entry strategy. First, find the general trend direction.  
  
**if (EMA62 > EMA200 && EMA200 > SMA800) Direction = 1; // Uptrend  
else if (EMA62 < EMA200 && EMA200 < SMA800) Direction = 2; // Downtrend  
else return(0); // Choppy trend  
  
**Next, make sure the 72, 24, 12, and 8 EMAs are stacked properly. (Reverse of this for a short of course.)  
**  
if (EMA72 < EMA24 && EMA24 < EMA12 && EMA12 < EMA8)  
  
**I have good luck with timing the entry using EMA24 and EMA8 on the M15 chart. (Reverse for a short.)  
  
**if (EMA24_M15 < EMA8_M15)  
  
**Finally, I look to see if the bid has pulled back to the EMA12.  
**  
if (Bid < EMA12)  
  
**I've been experimenting with the angles of EMAs 8 and 24 on the M30 chart. This seems to improve entries with some currencies, but not others. Still debating whether to include this in the finished product. (S1 and S15 refer to the parameter "Shift".)  
**  
if (EMA8_M30_S1/EMA8_M30_S15 > 1.0001 && EMA24_M30_S1/EMA24_M30_S15 > 1.0001 )  
  
**I exit when the EMA24 crosses the EMA12.  
  
Well, there you have it. I would MORE than welcome any and all comments that I could use to refine my criteria. I'm mainly concerned with making the EA work in a choppy market...or at least recognize this fact and not trade. Once it's done, I'm happy to post it...hopefully others can at least learn something from it.  
  
Kindest regards,  
Mango from British Columbia, Canada

hi there,  
  
if i get it right, u need a filter for the EA avoiding choppy times.  
  
here's the suggestion, u can try applying RSI with 14 period Close. and use only level 56 and 44 for the RSI.  
  
if the RSI is in between these 2 levels, tell the EA to avoid opening any post. while for buy definitely above 56 and below 44 for sell trigger in accordance to the Cornflower original rules.  
  
this RSI thingy has been suggested by someone in this forexfactory forum. but i dont remember who. and please remember I am not the originator of the idea. please give credit to the deserved ones.

Hi WARaintOVER,  
Cornflower is a trend continuation system. If you refer to the first port by lever, he mentioned about all MAs used in Cornflower.  
  
According to the rule, to initiate a position all MAs must line up approriately. For example, to go long, MA8 > 12>24>72\. In an uptrend, wait for the price to bullback between MA12 and 24. Watch the price bounce from that consolidation range and thats were long position is taken.  
  
CW

Well, it's been a long time since I've posted. It's nice to see this thread percolating along in my absence. I intend to start participating again.   
  
The market appears to be in flux. GBPUSD broke its weekly trendline. If it ends the week below it, we could see a futher decline of around (EDIT) 1200 pips (Tom DeMark's trendline methods gave me that figure). Of course, the market can do anything, so be vigilant. Cornflower will always tell you what the market IS doing, and you should always trade on that basis. Remember: Predictions are fictions!  
  
I have posted to the Trading Toom an overall outline of my method. You can't post there unless you have 1KT status, but feel free to ask me questions here and discuss amongst yourselves. Here's the link: <http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=61722>.  
  
Happy holidays and good trading!

As with any pull-back system, it seems that there is no definite point where a re-entry can be considered. In other words, it's all purely discretionary, although I would bow to lever70 if she differs in her opinion regarding Cornflower! For me, however, (and you, cyberwang, it seems), a less discretionary point of re-entry might make decisions a little easier. Which is why I've been playing around with small TL's whilst demo-ing the system. During a pull-back, I would usually wait for at least 3 candles before drawing the TL. If the TL is broken inside the 8/12ema area, this can, a lot of the time but not always, signify the start of a decent move and well worth a trade re-entry. However, if price has pulled back into the 12/24 or the 24/72 area, then regardless of TL breaks, for me it would definitely be a wait and see period. I'd just prefer to handle TL breaks and re-entries around the 8/12ema zone, but that's just me. Oh, and my re-entries would always be at the opening of a new candle after a TL break. Trader's discretion will always (rightfully) be required, but anything that helps with his/her final decision can't be bad, can it?  
  
Cheers.

Trends start to build from the lower time frames. I use the 5M TF for confirming the trend on the 15M (the 15M is the TF I prefer to use for most of my entrance decisions.)   
  
I like to see a strong trend on the 15M. I consider the trend to be fairly strong if the candle closes after crossing the 72 and the other three ema's are lined up in the direction of the trend (I also want to see at least two of the ema's have crossed the 72.)  
  
I would suggest picking one or two currency pairs (GBP/JPY, GBP/USD, EUR/USD are good to start with) and following them for several months. While the Weekly and Daily charts won't change much, the 4H, 1H, 30M, 15M, and 5M should give you a good feel for each individual pair. You will find that after a while, some TF's will work better for your eyes than others (some traders make their decisions on the 5M chart while others use the Daily or Weekly, and you will find followers of every other TF in between.) Purchase some notepads (I buy them by the dozen) and take copious notes. The more you do now, the better it will be later.  
  
I hope this was of some help.

I wait until the candle closes after crossing the 72 ema. I prefer to see it close with at least 25% of the body of the candle on the closure side of the ema.  
  
The direction and separation of the ema's are as important as the retracement. If the ema's are lined up and headed in the same direction, then there is a better chance of the trend continuing. If the ema's are bunched up and running flat or crossing over, the trend is not as strong. The steeper the angle of the ema's the stronger the trend. Also, the steeper the angle, the less the retracement.  
  
When I first started looking at the Cornflower system, I put four charts up side-by-side (Hourly, 30M, 15M, and 5M.) Each with the four ema's. I then studied the charts and their relation to price action. Patterns start to stand out after a bit of study.  
  
I hope the above was of help to you.
