i understand your question dpfuller, this was my problem when i first started off with this system, it has something to do with your "feel" for the system which you tend to attain once you have spent some time with this system. for now you just need to know that you want the price to "settle" between the 8 and the 24 ema's which means it could be somewhere between 8 and 12, or maybe on the 12 or right at the 24 ema.   
  
let me give you a few hints that will help you on your way  
  
1) newly build trends will tend to pull back right off the 8 ema if the trned is strong and showing good signs of staying for some time.   
  
2) mature trends will often find the support at the 12 ema or somewhere between the 12 and the 24 ema  
  
3) exhausted trends will often look to sneak right through the 24 ema (represented by long wicks below the 24 ema by a candle or an actual close below it...note: the pull back mgith still occur but an entry at this stage will be riskier)  
  
4) always enter at the start of the new candle don't be greedy, if you have missed the pullback candle look for other pairs, don't try to force your pips and squeeze them in your palm...they will work like fine sand, the more you press the more it slips through you fingers...![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f601.png?v=15.1)  
  
5) right so we enter at 00:00 of the new candle...?? wrong. you wait for atleast 5 mins of the 1 hour candle to see where the orice wants to go, again that helps in filtering some of the bad trades...if within 5 minutes you don't see a positve pullback sign wait further which will sometimes last the entire candle and we enter on the next candle  
  
6) as a beginner keep the aggressive entry of this system out of your head, this is how i made majority of my losses when i first started off with this system....note: by new i mean new to the system and not to forex trading necessarily...![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
7)**Look at multiple Time Frames pleeeeze!!!!!** this may seem tiring, but it is very very important, you need to have all the four ema's on more then just the 30 min and the 1H Tf. i use it on the 4H and the daily too. once you do it you'll notice that all of these pullbacks and CF features also occur on these larger TF's....sometimes you see a clear trend on the 30 min and the 1H yet the price goes against you...why? many a times the price found the 72 ema on the 4H which was nowheer near the price in the lower TF's!!! there are many other times when you'll see that the price actually wants to follow the larger TF's as well so do use them.  
  
8) if possible just do place another ema which is the 365 ema (applied to close) on all of these TF's....the reason is the price will "always" and no that's not an exaggeration...the price will always show respect to it, no matter what, if not right on it somewhere around it...it's very veryt powerful so do have this special ema to complement your 4 CF ema's too  
  
i think that's it, as you go deeper into the system you'll see how good it is, and it has much more to it then just this....i.e the pullback entry and the aggressive entry. you can use it in many other ways and in every system!  
  
Regards,  
Ghous

After using the posted "rainbow" Multiple Moving Average (MMA) chart for several weeks, it appeared that it could be improved by adding Bollinger Bands, as referred to by lever70's postings regarding her M5 template.  
  
The ForEx Factory has over 1,100 postings related to Bollinger Bands. It has been my observation that the price often stops at a Bollinger Band, in some time frame, prior to pulling back to a particular Cornflower line.

USDCHF: Fairly good results, though drawdowns can be as much as 50%. 45%-50% winning ratio ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Hi,   
  
I am a fairly new Forex trader and this is my first reply to this topic. I have read all the pages related to this topic and have learned every single aspect to this system. To be quite honest, I have been very successfull trading with Lever's setup.   
  
From what I have observed and experienced, this system became very popular and all of a sudden people began to walk away from it. I truly believe that the reason for this is that people are always in search for a Holy-Grail for whatever reasons or aspects of life there might be. There is a distorted notion that there's always a free ticket or an easy way out.   
  
The truth is straight and simple: there's absolutely no free lunch!   
  
Therefore, I must conclude that, from what I have experienced so far, this system works! You just have to be very patient and have the nerves to make it work! Not only this, but you will have to get your stuff together and do some studying behind it in order to combine this wonderful system with a couple of other useful data/information (deMarker - hint.) that will all work for you ultimately.  
  
As for Lever, I truly don't know her. I might say that she is my greatest inspiration in Forex trading. Once I saw her system, and understood her approach to life (and trading itself), I understood that even in financial trading, we need some kind of muse or inspiration. Lever (or Felicia for all I know) became my first inspiration in Forex trading. I thank her very much for this... Although its been an absolutely unconscious move.  
  
I believe she became a bit frustrated with people's lack of understanding of her system coupled with a misguided approach to trading. It can be quite exaustive trying to swim against a Tsunami... If you know what I mean...  
  
Or maybe she fell in love with someone and married... Lets always hope for the good.  
  
I also hope that she still keeps up with this thread.  
  
If so, she would be very happy to know that some people did learn her system and took her approach to trading for granted!  
  
Below, there are two good examples from a determined "student".  
  
Best,  
  
Jupiter.

Hi Lever,  
  
Thanks for your feedback! I guess we are all glad that you are ok!!  
  
Hope everything is fine and kicking! Welcome back and I would like to wish you the very best from beautiful Rio de Janeiro, Brazil!!!  
  
Now, back to trading...  
  
I know there's a lot of helpfull information about trading and so many different indicators, oscilators and systems. But from my short experience as an FX trader, I find that no other instrument is as helpfull as correctly drawing Support and Resistance lines.  
  
  
"I have seen people draw trend-lines from about anywhere on a chart from different threads here @ FF.  
  
So, allow me to put one strategy that might improve some of your drawings.  
  
An uptrend is when demand exceed supply, and bearish visa versa.   
  
So, how can we spot this events on our charts ?   
  
A strong support (demand-line) is when you have 2 bars to the left (bear-bars) and 2 bars to the right (bull-bars) and resistance the other way around. Look for this to occur for the second time and apply a line between this 2 points you have. Candlestick pattern like hammer / invert hammer would help the creditability of your lines too.   
  
Also correlate with different timeframes, don't get glued with only one timeframe !"  
  
Drawing correct support/resistance lines, will you help you very much. This combined with the trend indicator (Cornflower is great for this), will expand your chances of trading the brake in a successful way. As the pull back "hits" one of the EMAs (considering the "maturity" of the trend) and it rebounds to resume the trend, once it breakes either the resistance or the support lines, go for the trade. It will resume strong and the break will provide for a good ammount of pips. Just be carefull when you leave the trade... Don't get over exciited because it will be tempting! The pressure is high once it goes your way.  
  
Having said, I always look to place trades over the support/resistance lines that are in favor of the trend and specially after a pull-back. About an hour ago (13:00 EST) There was a strong pull back at CADJPY that came all the way from the 72 EMA! It was stong. I was a bit afraid of a turnaround, but once the pullback broke the resistance line... I knew I was in business. I went for 25 pips easily.  
  
I find that Tom DeMark Trendline is a very helpfull tool. I also know that Lever mentioned this before... So I will attach an indicator that will suit all of you that wish to trade the break along with cornflower. Hope it helps.  
  
Wish you all the Best.  
  
Jupiter.

First of all, I'm only trading EURUSD at the moment. An excellent pair for noobs and non-noobs alike, with a small spread and relatively stable and predictable price action. I quite like it, being a former cable junkie. And it's really good for short-termers, too. Unfortunately, the cornflower chart for EURUSD is a mess right now. In times like these, the shorter-term strategies I outlined come in real handy, and I have made a lot of pips in the last two weeks using them. It's been nice rediscovering trading. Apparently, I still know a thing or two about it. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
The intermediate trend is down on EURUSD, i.e., dollar-positive. As you know, I am not big on predictions. But I think this trend will continue, and then accelerate. I've been reading a lot of news and looking over long-term charts. My conclusion is that the end of dollar depreciation is near, if not already at hand. I will comment more on this soon. But the GBPUSD daily chart tells the story, soon to be replicated by EURUSD and then the other dollar currencies. (The parity party on USDCAD is done too.) There is a lot of chatter amongst government ministers in both the USA and EU, all of which amounts to a desire to see the dollar move higher.   
  
Watch your dollar shorts closely; they are likely to be reaction moves. Of course, your charts should be the basis for taking trades. But I suspect our money this year will be made on dollar longs. Of course, to quote Jacko, "I could be wrong!" ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)

Thank you, Lever, for sharing this method. I have studied the H1 approach for the last year and have just recently paper traded and now demoing it. Today I have recorded 5 wins out of 6 demo trades, just using the H1 retracement method, with limit orders, 10 pips Stops and PT set.......using MIG MT4 charts and demo account. Total pips = 120 won, 10 stopped, so 110 net.   
Potential profits (with hindsight) were much larger (and perhaps with practice I might eventually be able to realise greater rewards), but for now I am happy to set the trades with modest PTs and walk away to check results later........if I watch I am only too ready to hit the button as soon as I see a profit, depriving myself of a more respectable take as I see the price move on up after exiting.  
Hope this gives some encouragement to others to try Cornflower.....I do believe it offers high probability trades when used sensibly......best way is to do exactly as it says on the tin, ie read the instructions supplied by Lever and apply!

I will give an update on a currency at least once a day...  
Today i will show USD/CHF  
  
I am sorry for the size of the image guys...I whanted you guys to get a nice zoom in and i will explain what i see....  
  
Just by taking a look at the chart look at the wave formed from the low of june 9 to the high of june 11....and then compare it to the wave from the low of june 12 to the hihg of june 12 and last wave from the low of june 13 to the high of june 13....Just by looking at this you can see the waves getting smaller= that equals loss of streght. Second look how clean was the way back each wave and how you got each bounce of the fibb levels. Now simply by looking at the last day close look at how price started to make a,b,c,d down that shows more streght ont eh bearish side. Also price impacted a major tredline form a daily chart and it was simply a wick since all those candles above it are the wick on a daily candle. Alos if you place a fibb from the previous day swing price did not hit its 138.2 fibb that means weakness in the trend and possibell reversal coming up ahead...Also look at the angle of the 8 ema and 12 ema they are aiming down ...to me that shows that the short term trend is bearish....and that means dont go long unless price finds support below and hold the overall trend long in the 1 hour chart.  
  
If you guys have any question let me know. Once again sorry for the size of the picture just whanted to make sure you guys can look at it well.

No problem Adrian ... glad i can help out  
  
Well if you look at that chart (post 93) and where the arrows are you will see that there is about 20 pips between them, now i wont speak for lever but if i recall somewhere in this thread she said that 20 pips is a nice profit (remember shes a scalper at heart, 20 pips would be huge to her ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f61c.png?v=15.1)) so maybe thats why she put them there... as well as price is not rideing the top band as hard... im sure there are heaps of reasons but i guess you getting the idea?!  
  
Take that 5 min chart in post 93, if the EMA's had crossed back over then i would jump out of the trade there. If they just turned up again then i would keep rideing untill they cross. Thats just me .... Im not always right.... others have other ways of trading this system that are just as good!  
  
The longer term exit i like (but dont really trade cos who wants to be in a trade any longer then they need to be?)  
is the 8 crossing back over the 12 EMA on the hour.  
  
I also like risk/reward to be good, if i use a 20 pip stop im shooting for (but not locked into) a 30 pip profit target ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f911.png?v=15.1) ....... easier said than done!  
  
Hope this helps  
  
  
Bob

Thank you Bob. Tell me please, how do you enter on 5min chart after decision to enter is taken on 1h chart? How do you exit? just after 20-30 pips are reached? I use the 10 and 80 EMAs on 5 min.,which give a good entry point after crossing. Also,using Fibo levels, TD trendlines and BB and previous tops and bottoms or consolidations allow me to choose with very high rate an entry point from 8, 12, 24 or 72 EMAs on 1H. So,it is possible to choose the EMA of high probability pullback. MACD and STOCH I use for Diverganceies only. STOCH gives Divergence earlier than MACD or even MACD Histogramm. Thank you Bob for your efforts to help

I use Lever's 5 Min entry chart (around post 80-90 in this thread) and i guess i use it like her.... not so much into Bolinger Bands as she is but i guess they help!  
  
The first thing i work out for any trade is the stop level i am going to use, for me i want a stop of no more then 20pips, because i am always looking to keep my risk/reward ratio positive (1:1.5 is good) i would be looking to take 30pips on such a trade. so if the stop is to big then i don't take the trade and wait for the next one.  
  
I have attached a EUR chart that just took place with a nice 24 bounce, i only trade the 12 or 24 bounces. Trade what works for you ... I by no means am the template ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f609.png?v=15.1)

jdcompute,  
  
Thanks for explaining your reasons for entry and exit. I had made the mention that I wasn't criticizing your trade because after I made the post, I realized it had the look of me questioning you of not following the system correctly, and of course that was not the case. There are times when we make a post that it comes across to the reader differently than we intended. Thanks for understanding.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)  
  
As for the CF system, I've been following this system from the beginning when this thread started. Of the (demo) trades I've made, I've had good success. However, there have been 2 things that have been holding me back from really going full force and focusing totally on this top notch system.  
  
1\. Instead of picking a set way to trade the CF, I keep trying different ways to trade it. Such as: trying different time frames, entering on a pull back to the 12 ema, entering on a pullback to the 24 ema, entering on a pullback to the 62 ema, not waiting for a pullback but instead waiting for the MA's to angle/slope downwards or upwards, entering on a close of a candle, entering before the close of a candle, etc....  
  
By doing all these things I am not getting any consistency with trading this system. It's also very time consuming. I need to choose a set way to trade and go with it!  
  
2\. The other thing that is slowing me down is that I keep looking at other systems and trying them out. It's basically me getting into the thinking trap of, "The grass is greener on the other side of the fence." This thinking has played a part in bogging me down.   
  
I will say that having looked at many different trading systems, in my opinion, no system has yet to beat the CF system - when all things are considered. As I said, I'm always checking out other systems and when all is said and done, I continue to come back to the CF System. This system consistently performs well. Anyone can see this for themselves by doing backtests on it. There are other systems that do well but they are SO complicated! This is definitely not a problem with the CF system. The simplicity of the CF system is what sets it apart from most other systems. With it's consistent positive results, along with it's simplicity - and don't forget its relatively small stop losses (compared to many systems that require 50-100 pip or even larger stop losses)! - well, this system to me is hard for any other system to beat!  
  
As I said, If I can get myself settled down, only focus on THIS system, and pick only ONE way to trade it, I'll probably suprise even myself of how well I can do with this!  
  
  
Topgun 

"Success is not a fantasy, it's a formula." - MTI

Sherlina,  
  
Not sure this will help you but ill give it a go.  
  
Early on (maybe even post 1) Felicia makes a point about the 8 crossing the 12 as a "get out" signal for longer term trades. I don't use cornflower that way but on the chart i attatch ill try and outline how someone might do just that.  
  
I like the EMA's to all be stacked nice and in the right order, so the blue arrow shows a nice 12 EMA bounce and a great spot to get in short.  
  
The red arrow is just on the candle after the 8 EMA crossed the 12 EMA so this saying to me the trend (for now) is retracing so a good spot to get out, taking that trade this way would have got you over 100 pips.  
  
For me when the EMA's start crosing back over (on whatever timeframe you use) its time to sit on the fence, when its clear and stacked nice and clean its happy cornflower days.  
  
Hope this helps  
  
Bob

Lite,  
  
When i see price in the area of the 12 or 24 EMA's i then go to lever's 5 min chart to time my entry.  
  
Other people have posted other tools they use to help them with cornflower, just go back through the thread to see some of them, you have to use what works for you... not me. Having said that i feel cornflower is a simple system that should stay that way.  
  
The key for me with this system is not to over trade, there wont be trades everyday... the last week or more has been great as the cable, aud and others have been trending, we will go through some hard times again when the EMA's are all bunched up but as i said my key is waiting for the market to come to me.... im not runing after the market trying to find a trade.  
  
Hope this helps you get a handle on how i trade cornflower ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  
Bob

Jrex,  
  
The short answer to you question is: The market only moves in 3 directions, up, down and sideways.  
  
When the market is moving up or down thats a trend, cornflower is good at showing this because when the EMA's are lined up in the right order this shows a trend.  
  
Sideways is when the market is range bound or not doing much trending.... in cornflowe thats when the EMA's are all bunched up and not showing a trend.  
  
  
There is a lot more to this subject that you can (should) learn... a great place to start is babypips.com, they have a school system that shows all the basics of trading, a great place to fill in the blanks for people starting out.  
  
Hope i have helped  
  
Bob

kodflakes,  
  
Thats not really the way cornflower works, when we see the EMA's cross over and start to spread out (where you took your entry) that is when we start looking and watching for the market to retrace back to one of the EMA's, once this has taken place and the market has started moving back in the direction we want to trade.. we enter.  
  
take a look at the chart of an AUD trade i took last night, notice the green tick is where the trend restarts and the red arrow is the candle that bounced almost on the 24 EMA, giving me my entry.  
  
I think it's very good if people read post 1 again from time to time, i know i do and it keeps it all clear in my head, also the whole thread is a good read with lots of examples of how to trade cornflower.

Kodflakes, I use the Cornflower on 1 hour as my main trend. Like Bob says, wait for a pullback into the trend. If you have to look to hard for a trend...it's not there. I trade off the 15 minute charts. I use a 12 and 48 ema as my trend direction and don't trade against it. I mainly trade E/J. Check out E/J and G/$ lately, strong trends. I wait for a pullback into the 1 hr CF trend and wait for the 15 min 12/48 cross to line up in the same direction. Ideally I wait for a small pullback to be safe and wait for the break of support or resistance. The reason I chose to wait for a cross on 15 min was because I was getting burnt placing an order at the 24 hourly. I asked myself why do some stop there and others don't. Answer: I don't know. So I came up with the 12/48 and it seems to work for me.  
Hope this helps.

Really? I found that exits were not a problem for me, but entries were truly problematic. They are the main reason I abandoned this system months ago, after trying it for some (actually long) time in demo. Many others seem to have been quite successful with it, though, so the problem seems to be mostly mine.  
  
The reason for not having problems with the exits is that I simply used to stick to a predetermined plan. Sometimes I left plenty of profit on the table and some others I waited a little too long and got nothing, but that's how it is. That part more or less worked for me. Entries, however... I still have nightmares. Leaving aside the fact that every once in a while you'll get the dreaded reversal (happens with almost any trend-following system and there is no way around it), I still found extremely difficult to time the entry properly. If I entered at the touch of the 12 EMA in a moderately strong trend, more often than not price would keep going to the 24 (and sometimes beyond) and stop me out. Dropping to the 5M timeframe helped, but by the time you see price is already bouncing back... well, it is already bouncing back, and you have lost the advantage of the "touch" entry, might as well have entered blindly on the bar before. I am sure you are familiar with this. For some reason, it seems my psyche is not well suited to this kind of "EMA touch" entry and I executed it very poorly, many of my cornflower trades were stopped out in the bar after the entry. Recently I had a long backtesting session of the system (wanted to see how it felt after months without using it) and it is still the same for me, I am unable to get the entries right.  
  
Anyway, I am glad you are doing well with this system. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)

Sometimes I left plenty of profit on the table and some others I waited a little too long and got nothing, but that's how it is. That part more or less worked for me. Entries, however... I still have nightmares. Leaving aside the fact that every once in a while you'll get the dreaded reversal (happens with almost any trend-following system and there is no way around it), I still found extremely difficult to time the entry properly. If I entered at the touch of the 12 EMA in a moderately strong trend, more often than not price would keep going to the 24 (and sometimes beyond) and stop me out. Dropping to the 5M timeframe helped, but by the time you see price is already bouncing back... well, it is already bouncing back, and you have lost the advantage of the "touch" entry, might as well have entered blindly on the bar before. I am sure you are familiar with this. For some reason, it seems my psyche is not well suited to this kind of "EMA touch" entry and I executed it very poorly, many of my cornflower trades were stopped out in the bar after the entry. Recently I had a long backtesting session of the system (wanted to see how it felt after months without using it) and it is still the same for me, I am unable to get the entries right.

Pipadder,  
  
It seems like you are finished trading the system and I am not sure if anyone else if trading like this but I can tell you a little bit about my own personal modifications...I was having a difficult time with entries as well because that is something that needs to be a "for sure" thing whereas exits I can figure out on my own.  
  
So, what I've been doing is if the market is in a downtrend (EUR and GBP the past 12 hours) is placing a stop entry below the low of the candle that touches one of the EMA's. Now that doesn't filter every entry but it keeps my mind at ease in case the market continues to rally to the next EMA. Which did happen atleast twice today.  
  
I do this completely on the 5m chart whereas the Hourly I enter on the touch of the EMA because there is just too many pips lossed if you enter short below that hourly candle.  
  
Just my two cents but hope this helps anyone interested. 

Chance favors the prepared mind.

qwer2004,  
  
First up i just want to make sure it's clear i was talking about a question from Christ. Jast and that question was:  
  
"How long (and strong) should be trend to "safety" trade? - what do you think?"  
  
Ok so i will assume that you have an idea of how cornflower works, if not go and read post one because all anyone needs to know to get started is there.  
  
First when looking for a cornflower trade i need the EMA's to be stacked in the right order to show a current trend, the chart in this post shows a white circle around where the EMA's are bunched up and then starting to spread out in order - this shows me the start of a trend i may want to trade.  
  
The 2nd thing i look for is has there been a trade already in this current trend? the way i trade is waiting for a pullback to either the 12 EMA or 24 EMA, in this chart the red arrow show the "first trade".  
  
The 3rd thing i want and am now waiting for is a 2nd pullback (shown by the green arrow in the chart) if this pullback dose what i want and resumes the trend then i enter a trade.   
  
  
Some people might say i am letting to many pips go, others might not like idea of waiting around when trade was there the first time... and thats fine but i know this works for me.  
  
  
I hope this was clear... i'm not sure it was but let me know how your trading is going too!  
  
Bob![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)

Iceman,  
  
That trade got me... it went and hit my stop before it went on down ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f633.png?v=15.1) so maybe my stop was to close? not really, thats the risk level i am happy with and they were HUGE candles so maybe i could just stay out the market if its like that!  
  
Your spot on about moving stops and such, what i do now is something i got from the fokes over at the DIBS thread which is to set up the trade in 2 lots.  
  
1st lot I set the trade up so the risk:reward is 1:1,   
2nd lot I ride the trend and take profit where i always would, the great thing about this is once the 1st profit target is hit its a "free" trade as i lose no pips if i get stopped out and by not moving the stop to B/E the trade has room to move.  
  
I know thats not what others will like to do but we all trade differnt ways

Bob,  
  
On those 4hrly charts it is tough because stops have got to be very wide. I am glad to see you are incorporating two smaller lots. My profits have gone through the roof on the 5min chart because of it.   
  
When it comes to risk:reward ratios - I don't get too hung up if my stop is 25 pips I have to take 25 pips profit initially. Setting things in stone is, in my humble opinion, not a place where a discretionary trader should be. Always analyze the charts and see what is best. You might realize that you should go for a smaller initial profit because the trend might be slowing down or whatever, but your stop might have to be a bit wider to accommodate the volatility of today's markets.  
  
Just a thought as always. I hope that between the two of us we can try to keep this thread alive as it has benefited me beyond what most can understand. I might have to start my own thread to discuss my modified strategy and my own personal viewpoints.  
  
Until then, trade with the trend and keep it simple. Trading is only made difficult if you make it that way.  
  
God Bless.

I am going to post a few select charts with some ideal and not so ideal trades from last week. (9-22-08 -- 9-26-08) My settings are just slightly different than the original. My EMA's are 16, 24, and 43. I stuck with the 24 because it seems to work quite well but I changed to the 16 and 43 because they have worked for me a bit better.   
  
Attached is 2 Charts. The first is a EURUSD Chart from 9-22. There are blue boxes that I used to highlight each area where a trade can be attempted. I do not enter all of these because I am sleeping some of the times. Starting with the box to the far left which I will refer to as #1 and each box will be referred to as the next number in order. #1 is a good 24EMA Trade that I entered to the right side of the actual blue box.  
  
This trade I entered and yielded +25 and +45 pips. #2 is a trade worth entering at either the 24 or 43. I was luckily asleep and missed that trade because it would have been a losing trade based on my parameters which is usually a 25 pip stop. #3, I was awake for and took but got in late. It obviously did not truly touch the 24EMA but with such a reversal bar off of that level I took the trade.   
  
Another thing to keep in mind is that monday's are typically a trendy day with good profits for a system like this and that is also the reason why I took the trade. I would not have taken the trade any other day. I got +25 and +52 on that trade. At this point I quit for the day because I had two winning trades and there were any more trades until the #4 box. I did not take this even though I was watching because the trend was so far extended that I knew this was more of a risky pullback, in which it would have resulted in a loss. No EA can beat an open eyed discretionary trader with no greed.  
  
Now on to the next day in the EURUSD (9-23-08) where the day was not as perfectly ideal. Not that you can't make good pips but knowing how far the market extended itself on monday, you must keep in mind that trades need to managed more diligently.  
  
Box #1 is a perfect setup where the EMA's are "stacked" and there is a good trending market. I took a short at 4748, I believe, and took +20 and +42. My schedule is that I wake around 2-3am EST and if there is an opportunity I wait and take it. If nothing then I rewake at 5 and then 7. If the EMA's are in trending mode then I'll wait up but if not then I go back and sleep. Once NY session is open I am up all day because I also trade the grain markets.   
  
Box #2 is a trade that I was not awake for because I had taken profit earlier but this is a perfect setup that just didn't work out. Either EMA would have resulted in a loss but this is no problem at all. We are merely trading with the odds that over time we will come out on top.  
  
Box #3 is also a trade that I was not awake for and quite questionable as to whether there was profit. If you would be going for +20 then you would have gotten your initial but then break even on the second position. If you went for 25 to 30 then I believe you would have taken a double loss. Nevertheless, it was a good set up once again.  
  
Box #4 is a trade entry that I missed by 1 pip. I place limit orders and move them every 5 minutes so that I can take advantage of moves like this that are only at the price level for an instant which is difficult to stare at the screens like that for so long. That trade would have yielded +25 and +0 if taken.  
  
Box #5 is a trade that I did enter and got me worried at one point with the price spike. Haha. I place my stops at -25 though so it never hit. I did get +25 and +43 on that trade. A very choppy market at the time which is difficult because ultimately the day fell much harder. No worries though because you can't predict anything...all you can do is follow a system and not regret missing out on things.  
  
I hope this helps anyone trying to find a system that works. Any questions are welcome as I am sure I skipped some things and maybe some would like to dig deeper into how I make certain decisions.  
  
God Bless.

For this post I will talk about the GBPUSD on the following 2 days (9-24 to 9-25) No particular reason because I do trade both and which ever setup (sometimes both) appeals to me then I take that trade.  
  
Starting with 9-24-08. Box #1 is perfect setup where the EMA's split just in time for me to take a long. Any earlier and I would not have been able to justify a trade. I got +22 and +43 out of that one.  
  
Box #2 is another trade that I was awake for but ended Breakeven on both trades. My initial profit was missed by just a pip or two and so I moved my stops up because that is too close. That turned out to be the intelligent thing to do.  
  
Box #3 was a shrot trade that I missed. As the day progressed it was a perfect setup but very volatile and you would have more than likely gotten stopped out. There is actually another trade that I am seeing that I missed about half way between #3 and #4. A good short could have been taken there but I did not see that until now.  
  
Box #4 was another perfect setup that hit my second profit target perfectly merely by luck, in my opinion. So +25 and +45 on that trade.  
  
Box #5 was another good setup that I took. I ended up +25 and +0 because of the retrace right before 1500. It could have yielded much better profit but better to be breakeven knowing you cannot lose any pips.   
  
The next chart is GBPUSD on 9-25-08. Boxes #1,2,and 3 are all good setups that I just wanted to point out. These are during the asian session and pre london open. It seems to me that the slower times yield as good of profits as the more volatile times. Less chance of getting stopped as well.   
  
Box #4 is where I began and took 2 losses -25 and -25. Box #5 is a little modification that I personally do quite well with. When it seems to me that there is a trend reversal (in this case long reversing to short side bias) then when price breaks the 43 and retraces when all 3 EMA's are together I'll take a position (in this case short) in anticipation of more follow through with a tight stop. +25 and +52 on that trade.  
  
Box #6 I took two losses on a good setup. This is a tough pill to swallow since it ended down on the day afterwards but I would have to have more than 50 pips on my stop to be safe on that one. I don't really care at that point losing but seeing the market fall with no real pullbacks until box #6, which I did not take because I missed the major move of the day.

Box #1 is a great short when the retracement was actually just a flattening period until the EMA's caught up which is my personal favorite trade to make.4638 was my short and I took profit at 4613 +25 and 4582 +56 with S1 in mind.  
  
Box #2 was also another short I took which got me a little concerned but luckily the 43 stopped the market. I took profit of +25 and +16. The exits were alittle different because of box #3 which I was still in my second position but then missed my second profit target by a few pips. That should not have been because I should have just exited at the S1 level again. Not really greed but I was hoping for lower lows.  
  
Box #3 was no entry because I was still in the #2 trade but could have still produced some profit.  
  
Box #4 was a clear long entry loss that I took for -25 and -25. I usually don't like to take positions when the market reverses rather than retraces slowly. Ths happened so fast though that I did not have time to cancel orders. Not a bad setup though so I can not regret.  
  
Box #5 and #6 I did not take because if you look at overall price movement it was down earlier (london open to about 0600) then up, then down, then up, then down again....on a friday. These are possible trades I wanted to point out but the open eyed discretionary trader will not enter in these market conditions, especially on a friday.  
  
God Bless.

Last evening and today I only traded the EURUSD. There were profits in the GBP but I looked over my account statement of recent past and realized that there were many more losses in the GBP. I took a look at the price movement/structure and see many more violent spikes and decided to re-analyze whether I want to trade both or just focus on one. Today, I traded the EUR only.  
  
Box #1 was from last evening and I did take that trade. I had to leave to I placed my stop and limits for both positions at +/-25pips. I took profit on that trade. Box #2 I missed and luckily I did because there was a fake breakout type movement that would have resulted in a loss.  
  
Box #3 was another good trade that I missed as I was not home at the time. Box #4, 5, and 6 are excellent trades. I entered at #6 and proceeded to make +25 and +65 pips. Box #7 I entered but then exited at breakeven because I wanted to go back to sleep and things didn't look too promising. That was a mistake and I missed out on good profits.  
  
Box #8 was another good trade but one that I missed. Darn what a great cornflower day! Box #9 I did enter and took +25 and +0...well actually +.5 but who cares about half a pip.  
  
Box #10 I took +25 and +43 pips and decided that I was done. That type of winning streak is bound to become overtraded and that is exactly what would have happened if I traded Box #11. The market spiked and then returned to flat since then. Absolute patience is a must in trading. I realize that I can control my losses and never over trade then the profits will come like they did today. I might have missed some trades but I know full well that I would have taken them so I count them as profit too. That is how I knew not to trade any more today.  
  
+208 pips today. I must be careful tomorrow as it might be a consolidation day and I will have to wait for clear trends if I want a good trade to produce.

I love trading sunday nights into monday. They always have such strong trending movements and with all of this market volatility it makes it even better! I only have trades on this chart from late last night but I was taking shorts in the New York afternoon/evening as well that gave me some good pips.  
  
Box #1 is a very nice retrace but I just exited a trade from earlier and this was when I went to lay down for a bit. Box #2 is a place where you could hav gotten multiple entries if you didn't get in on the first hit. What a great trade that would have been as well. Box #3 was right before I woke up so I missed that trade but Box#4 I did enter and took +25 and +37 because of the S2 pivot line.  
  
Box #5 is another trade that I took but was not too sure because of the strong gap down at the open earlier and the close proximity of S2 and its obvious strength. Lo and behold, it was a loss. -25 and -25 but no worries.  
  
Box #6 was a nice long setup that I gladly took. I entered at 3588 and took profit at 3613 (+25) and 3643 (+55). Wow! What a close one. I always take a good profit short of the pivot but that was purely divine intervention.  
  
Sadly though at Box #7 I took another double loss of -25 and -25. That was a good setup that I quickly jumped into with a little bit of confidence. This is a time when I look back in hindsight and say to myself..."this is a game of probabilities not what trades you like or don't like. Forget nice trades and just follow the system." How true because just when you think this is a perfect bounce for higher highs it reverses.  
  
Box #8 I missed because I had some things to do but was an absolute perfect trade but one thing to remember. This is why it is best to watch the markets but move a limit order instead of hoping you have quick enough hands. That price looked like it bounced very quickly.  
  
Box #9 is where I did go short and I took +25 and +25, conservatively. I felt no need to go for more pips even though now it looks as though we might be getting lower lows and I type this.No worries...there are always more trades everyday on the 5min chart.  
  
God Bless.

Well these are come crazy days we are dealing with and the system has proven itself to some extent for me even in the ugliest of markets.  
  
10-7-08 Euro was quite the hectic trading session. Box #1 I did not trade but turned to be a loser by 2 pips past the 25pip stop that I would have had. Box #2 was a good trade but I only took +25 on the first position and break even on the second. It missed my profit target by a few pips. Box #3 was a clear loser with -25 and -25.   
  
Box #4 was an awesome trade that gave me +25 and then I set my second position at break even but as you can see I lost connection. Haha...I was stressed but everything worked out. Box #5 actually stopped me out for -25 and -25 again! But I reentered when the market showed support at the EMA's. I only got +25 and +0 though. So it was becoming quite tough at this point and then Box #6. The market went right down to my stop and then went back and forth for a while. At this point with another -25 and -25 I decided to call it quits for the day. No Big deal...I needed a losing day sooner or later.  
  
10-8-08 Euro was another crazy day and I am done trading already this morning. Box #1 was a nice short that I was hoping for lower lows but only got +25 and +0. No Problem and that has since proved to be the low for the day. Box #2 was a nice trade even though I didn't like the 5 min candle that took a nose dive towards the EMA's. I expected this one to be a loser. I got +25 and +0 and was hoping that trade would be one I could let run as well for higher highs. Not this time!   
  
Box #3 was a straight out loser that proved to be a good long trade a few hours later. -25 and -25 on that one. Box #4 was my last trade for the day and it went for -25 and -25.  
  
These are days that test your determination in a system. I know that there is an edge with the cornflower trading but these days are range bound volatility which is some of the most difficult to trade. I used to trade a breakout system and these days would drive me insane. I would be going long at the high of the day and short at the low...I've since learned a better way.  
  
God Bless.

Qwer,  
  
My decision to take profit is based off of a few things. First is if there is a pivot line close I will take profit a bit short of that. Second, on monday's there is usually more follow through for whatever reason so I will be more patient and take profit at a higher level. Third, I take profit on both positions at +25 when I have had somewhat of a losing day and just need the pips and the market isn't really following through. That has burnt me though because sometimes the real trends happens in the NY afternoon which is my favorite time to trade because there is less whipsaw volatility.  
  
I take most positions at the 24 ema but I have changed a couple of things and have mentioned these sparingly. I don't really trade the GBPUSD much anymore except on monday's because there is more trending movement BUT I still compare what is going on in the GBPUSD with the EURUSD.   
  
That is because if, for example, there is a downtrend and both are retracing I will take a look over to the GBP. If the GBP has already broken the 24 and 43 to the upside then I will move my entry on the EUR to the 43. That way I know that I have a less chance of getting stopped. I don't really reference this too often in my descriptions so I thank you for asking that great question.  
  
God Bless you too and I hope I answered your questions fully.

Well another day another dollar or should I saw Euro? Hey Bob, great trade but I can't tell you what is going to happen since the euro has already fallen almost 3000 pips from 1.60.   
  
This is a day where patience pays off and diligently sticking to the system.  
  
Box #1 is a trade that techincally would have been profitable but I took a good entry on basically the same trade at Box #2. I got +25 and +0 because of the return back to the EMA's. Box #3 could have been another entry but that is where I took the breakeven trade. That would have been an obvious loser.  
  
Box #4 was a perfect setup but I had no clue where to take the second profit so I took +25 and +25. Box #5 was another great short at 3442 almost exactly. I took +25 and +31 from the most recent low just a half hour before.  
  
Box #6 was not a trade that I really wanted to take because of it being the 3rd retracement and wishing I had held on much longer with the previous two trades. Profit target was missed by only a few pips and ended -25 and -25.  
  
Box #7 was the breakout/retracement of the longer term EMA that I have been speaking about. Very nice trade but I missed it and was regretting that one more than anything.   
  
Box #8 was pretty crazy. I did not get stopped but came within about 3 pips I think. The market then rallied like crazy and I took +25 and then missed my next profit target at 3497 but .9 of a pip! So that one went breakeven.  
  
Box #9 was the one I was hoping to rally to higher highs for the day but then I remembered it was friday with no serious econ news. I ended up taking -25 and -25 on the spike down before the little rally. Frustrating.  
  
I ended the day at +51 pips. I am plenty happy with that but need to learn to stop sleeping so I can get more trades.

Aarangio,  
  
No problem with the questions...the more we ask the better we all become!  
  
Yes, I use a 25pip stop on all positions. It is what has worked for me on the 5min chart. Just enough room for volatility, tight enough to keep losses to a minimum, and easy to remember.  
  
I do trade with 2 lots. I always take the initialy profit at +25 and then move my stop to break even for the other position. At that point I decide on recent S/R, pivots, and sometimes just an eye for the chart for my exit. The big negative with 2 lots is the double loss when you do take a loss. So you need to be adjusting your money management for a 50 pip loss and not 25.   
  
I cut my trade equity in half so that I was trading the same amount but in a dual entry format. I have been contemplating going back to a single position for some time but I have too much regret when I see a nice move for 50 or more pips after my entry. Personal preference is very important and the ability to self-analyze so that you can reach a positive conclusion is what each individual trader needs to do.  
  
I only trade the EUR but I do trade the GBP on mondays because I recognized there seems to always be a nice trend on monday.   
  
Box #8 I entered at 1.34381 and placed my stop at 1.34131. The low was 1.34154. I took initial profit at 1.34631 and my second take profit was at 1.34970. That missed by .9 of a pip. I cannot remember exactly why I chose 1.34970 but there must have been some justification!  
  
I enter at the 24EMA at all times EXCEPT when the GBP hasn't retraced at all yet. Then I sometimes will wait for the EUR to go to the 43 and that is usually when the GBP is reaching the 43. Vice versa - Sometimes the GBP is already at the 43 so I know the enter immediately at the 24. That is not set in stone because both operate fairly independently.   
  
The only time I would trade with a confirmation style is if there is a strong trend and I want to find a way to enter. I will wait for a retrace to the 16. Place a stop entry on the opposite side of the candle that touched and see if I get filled. For a short I would place a sell stop below the low of the candle that touched the 16. I dont really do that anymore becaues there are enough retraces for good trades at the 24 and 43.  
  
I hope this answers all of your questions!  
  
God Bless.

My advice to you is POSITION SIZE!!!! This is what works for me... 100 pip loss=2% of your capital. For a $5000 dollar account you trade 1 mini-lot. DO NOT VIOLATE THIS RULE.   
  
Also, what I use for a stop is a visual one. I do not use a pre-set stop-loss (aka 'target for your broker to take out'). My stop-loss is: if there is a 1HR bar close past the 72EMA against my position, it is a loss. You will notice in Cornflower that after a big move, the first return to the 72EMA is a very strong support. The 72 is the line in the sand. If it closes past it, you lost this trade, look for your quickest exit. LET THE BAR CLOSE and then make a decision. It is an emotionless process.   
  
For PROFIT, I look for recent lows/highs and I also use Bollinger Bands for reasonable exits. DO NOT BE GREEDY!!! Leave the top and bottom 15% for the risk-takers. We don't need that, just take the meat off the bone and go home.  
  
Another huge thing is this... jump up to the 4HR chart and use the same EMA's as the 1HR and determine the 4HR trend. Your 1 HR Cornflower entries must match the 4HR trend! NO EXCEPTIONS!! If the 1HR says go long, but the 4HR is short, you have NO TRADE.  
  
I will be lurking around for awhile, so if there are any Cornflower specific questions you have, I would be glad to help anyone attempting to learn the finer points of what has been presented so far.

> Another huge thing is this... jump up to the 4HR chart and use the same EMA's as the 1HR and determine the 4HR trend. Your 1 HR Cornflower entries must match the 4HR trend! NO EXCEPTIONS!! If the 1HR says go long, but the 4HR is short, you have NO TRADE.

  
I also very much believe that the time-frame above your main trading time-frame needs to be trending at the same time (as your main trading time-frame). As in your example, the CF lines on the 4 hr chart should match the CF lines on your 1 hr main trading chart. If you are trading the 5 mn chart, then the 15 min chart needs to be trending in the same direction. In fact, it would probably be a good idea if the 1 hr was also trending in the same direction as well (for a 5 mn trade).

it's not just brokers, topgun, it's the whole industry. it's obvious where some stops will be placed by the majority of traders, and the big fish in the sea will try to take those stops out.   
  
When I say I use a visual stop it is this - If the 1 HR bar closes past the 72, it is a loser and I will close the trade manually, AT A LOSS, when it returns to the 24. I only acknowledge BAR CLOSES with this method. Go back and backtest and see how many wicks break the 72 without there being a close past it, or how many S/R levels are 'broken' only to have it return in the direction you planned on. I set Take Profits on every trade. I do not set stop losses. If my trade identifies itself as a loser, I move the Take Profit to the next reasonable exit area and let the trade close itself out. This is how I minimize my losses.  
  
This is the most powerful realization of my last month - using the bar close past the 72 as my indicator that this trade is a loser. The other one is that I have finally dialed in the position size using my 100 pips = 2% rule. I rarely lose 100 pips, but this has been pure gold for me, I can handle the drawdown that occurs with this method.

this is something I am currently working on. I'm glad you brought it up. Yes, the most conservative thing to do is close the trade the moment the bar closes past the 72. I highly recommend this. It is the easiest way out and is emotionless and requires no thought. It closes past 72, IT'S A LOSER, close the trade!  
  
However, if you have used Bollinger Bands, you will notice an inevitable return to the midline, which is a 20 SMA, which is very close to the 24 EMA in value. So when the bar closes past the 72 EMA and I know I have a stinker of a trade, I don't just panic and close it, I instead look to the midline Bollinger Band, aka the 24 EMA, and I set my Take Profit to be at that level (most likely closing out at a loss), and wait for price to make it's natural return there. Basically I am alway letting price come to me. Go and backtest and see that price ALWAYS returns to these averages. The averages may be higher/lower than you'd like when price finally gets there, but the fact is, price ALWAYS returns to it at some point. So you might as well just set your trades to close out at those levels. You control the trade, do not let it control you. Look, see and set limit orders and take profit levels, shut the computer off and walk away for a few hours, come back and reevaluate.  
  
The reason I can trade this way is my POSITION SIZING. I trade with the right amount to handle the drawdown that occurs. My 2% of my account=100 pips rule is pretty golden, though slightly aggressive. 1%=100 pips is better for beginners I'd say.

> [Quoting hitman047](/thread/post/2373687#post2373687 "View Quoted Post")
> 
> Disliked
> 
> Can you help us explain what the "actual", "forecast" and "previous" numbers mean in the calendar? What do those numbers represent?
> 
> Ignored

Previous - the number last time the report was released.  
  
Forecast - the consensus on what the upcoming number should be  
  
Actual - the news number itself. Deviations from the forecast will move the market on a red news release.   
  
Do not be in the market at news time unless you are already in a long term position. Brokers widen [spreads](/brokers/spreads "View Live Spreads on the Broker Guide"), and you will find yourself in a bad spot.   
  
Do not try and guess what the number will be. That's gambling, pure and simple. News can move the market 100 pips or more in a very short period of time. Also, do not trade news using an autoclick program. That was a good game a couple of years back, but brokers have long since gotten hip to it.   
  
We have to be aware of when the news comes out to protect ourselves. You can attempt to trade the move after the spike, once spreads have returned to normal. This can be accomplished using my 5/10 system that I outlined earlier in the thread. Don't worry too much about the news itself. As I've always said, just trade with the market.

Looking back through some recent posts, I'm seeing a lot of indicators being added. I've always made a point of saying that traders shouldn't rely so heavily upon indicators, and I still feel this way. If indicators make you feel more comfortable about taking a trade, then pick just one and stick with that one only. But you are really better off without them.  
  
Indicators are derived from price. As such, they lag what price is actually doing. You are much better off trading on price action.   
  
Yes, EMAs are indicators. But I've found that they are the least of all evils. They represent the movement of price over time, and price tends to gravitate back toward a mean. This is why Cornflower works.   
  
Indicators other than moving averages, in my opinion, are largely voodoo. They lull traders into a false sense of control over events and distract us from paying attention to what price is actually doing. We get paid only if we are right on price. Cornflower aims to gauge price direction.   
  
The only other indicators I've used are (a) bollinger bands on my 5/10 chart to gauge volatility, and (b) cross-currency correlations. I haven't discussed correlations here, but they are invaluable. Typically, EURUSD moves with GBPUSD, and they are opposed by USDCHF and (to some extent) USDJPY. So if USDCHF is going up, GBPUSD and EURUSD should be going down.  
  
Even if you only trade EURUSD, you should watch the other pairs. If the point of indicators is to predict the future, then we should be watching all four of these pairs at once. More often than not, when the GBPUSD moves, the EURUSD follows, and the USDCHF goes in the other direction. It's usually cable that moves first, though this is not always true. The point is, more often than not one currency pair will tell us where the others are going.  
  
Go to <http://www.mataf.net> and look at the correlation tables, which are updated frequently. They will help you in making your trading decisions.

I don't have much to add at the moment. But trade vigilantly and protect your profits.  
  
We are in the midst of a financial crisis whose outcome is far from clear. Liquidity is thin because market participants don't trust one another. Remember that the forex market is comprised primarily of banks, and they are all playing defensive right now. There is an unwillingness to commit capital, and a general sense of mistrust. In illiquid markets, the moves are sudden and swift, and can't be easily predicted. As I type this, I am watching the EURUSD zoom up 40 pips in an hour, with violent downswings along the way. This type of action never used to happen in the early hours of Asia trading. It is now near-routine. There are, of course, opportunities in this kind of action. But be careful. Trade what you see, and guard yourself against trading on expectations of how things "should" happen. The past is the past. We are in a different era than we were a year or even six months ago, and everything is suspect.  
  
I am currently using Cornflower as a means to gauge (oh look, EURUSD just dropped 15 pips) general market sentiment, but am relying on my shorter-term systems for actual trades. I'm willing to take any and all questions relating to these. Mind you, they are not for the faint of heart. Then again, trading isn't more generally.

Hello Lever, I've been lurking for the past several months and have been playing with my demo account using the basic 1hr CF method.   
  
So far, I've been very sucessful WHEN I follow the CF rules. The only time I get into trouble is when I try to predict a CF set up and get in a bit too early.  
  
One of the more challenging aspects is finding a good exit strategy. I think paying attention the the daily/weekly support and resistance levels, pivot points..etc.. is key, but being a FX newbie...I'm still trying to understand what they really mean...![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f615.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/2753.png?v=15.1)  
  
I think what this CF system has really shown me is that along with understanding the technical aspects of FX trading...you need to work on your emotional side as well.   
  
\- don't get angry at the market  
\- don't see a good CF set-up - don't make a trade - walk away.  
\- patience will be rewarded  
\- indicators = noise  
  
Finally, thank you Lever and the rest of the regular posters for sharing.  
  
Happy Holidays

I have been using the CF H1 MA settings on H1 and M30 TFs and the M5 MA settings on M5 only. I have added STARC bands and Fractals (for a bit of convinience) and ZigZag. I like mutlitimeframes gearing, since M5 to M30 is a 1 to 6 time ratio. I also use Cf as originally designed to H1 TF, and pay attention to the performance of the 72EMA. I trade only GBP/USD and it is possible to scalp both ways in relation to the direction of the EMA72 on H1, but going against it demands a tighter SL and taking smaller profits. Going in the direction of this 72EMA on H1 allows one to miss the smaller cycle/s and still come out with profits, as the trend on a larger TF is less likely to change.  
Best wishes to all and many good trades,  
2be

If one has patience and gets rid of the gunslinger attitude you will make great money with this simple approach. Watch the weekly/daily and use the 4 hr as your template and your life will become so much easier.   
  
I feel with the correct money management rules...not over trading and let your winners run you will become a very successful investor.  
  
Just my 2 cents.

This has come up again here and in other places. Regarding a Cornflower EA, I devised Cornflower as a discretionary system, and I think it's best traded that way. No computer can replicate the judgment of an experienced, disciplined trader. There have been a number of attempts to automate Cornflower but no one has yet succeeded in devising an EA that is truly workable. The problem with Cornflower is that it's a trend-following system, and if every entry is taken there are going to be periods of drawdown in ranging markets. There is no way around it. Sure, we can write an EA with fixed profit targets of 20 or 50 pips, but the profits that result will mostly be eaten away by the inevitable losses in unfavorable market conditions. It's not the fault of the system. The market is unstructured and does not obey one set of rules at all times. As traders, we have to adapt to prevailing conditions, and adjust our decisions accordingly.   
  
That said, I encourage further work for those up to the task. I think any EA that incorporates Cornflower would need to be adaptive to market conditions, taking into account short- to mid-term fluctuations in volatility, average daily range, and multi-currency correlations. We'd also need to take into account support and resistance on multiple time frames, which is difficult to code with reliability. Pivot points are often cited as a solution to this problem, but I have found their usefulness illusory.  
  
I'm glad interest in the system is still strong after all this time. February was a frustrating month for those trading the USD pairs, but rewarding to those who traded long XXXJPY. The market will find its bearings before too long.

Hey Bob!  
  
Good eye for the charts. You might just be converted someday to the lower times frames. My setups are a little bit different because of the different time period ema's but all in all it is very close.  
  
I wanted to comment on the comment that you made concerning the crossing of the 72 or in my case the 43ema...  
  
I have personally found that there is a losing trade that preceeds this happening (obviously because price broke down and did not continue on the trend). When price breaks through the 43ema, the shorter ema's are typically stacked correctly on the downside (in this case) and then what I have found is a high probability trade when price FIRST retraces to the 43ema.   
  
Typically the shorter term ema's are close to the longer term ema when this happens so you have a ton of resistance from 3 ema's all at once.   
  
This chart I posted gives 2 examples:  
Box #1 is a failure and a losing trade. But Box #2 is a retrace afterward that does end in a profitable trade atleast for me. Notice the ema's are all at one place. Not real text book because of all that volatility but it got the job done.  
  
Box #3 is a losing trade that was quite the nice setup. Box #4 is a trade that I took on the short side and gave plenty of pips. This example is more textbook because I don't like too many bars to print before this retracement happens or I feel like it is more like violent whipsaw action than anything. (that statement relating back to boxes #1 and #2)  
  
I hope this helps and it will get you in on some early trend reversals from a true trend retracement.  
  
God Bless.

Hi everyone, I have some good news! A Cornflower EA has finally been created! I think this is the very first Cornflower EA posted in this thread that automatically takes the trades for us! I did see another EA here, but it just gave arrows and audio alerts of trade setups, but it did not take the trades automatically...it required the trades to be taken manually. However,**this** EA takes trades _automatically_.

  
Earlier this week I posted in the "Programming Discussion" section of FF a thread requesting someone to make an EA for our wonderful Cornflower system. Only one person was kind enough to agree to make the EA for us ... and he was nice enough to do it for free. His name is Postrock and I want to thank him for making this EA for us. Thanks Postrock!  
  
I will say, however, that I have not yet tested it ... so I hope I'm not being too premature in posting it here right now. I just want to let everyone know that an EA is available right now and I wanted to give everyone an early chance to test it.   
  
With this EA you have to set your own stops and targets. You also have to set your own timeframe and your number of lots you want to trade. You can also choose any of the Cornflower ema's you want as the trigger ema (the ema you want a trade to enter on when it touches).  
  
Even though I still think trading manually is probably the best way to trade this system (or any system for that matter), I think it is worth a try to see if an EA can actually be profitable. I figure there's no harm in trying (just be sure to test it thoroughly with a demo account before using a live account).  
  
Here is the link to Postrock's post of the EA. In his post he explains in more detail about the EA and the settings. Without further delay, here the link the the message by Postrock that has the EA:  
  
[http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost...3&postcount=13](http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=2618703&postcount=13)  
  
Happy Trading!

I'm really suprised nobody here has not said anything at all about the Cornflower EA that has finally been developed.  
  
As I remember, throughout this thread there were several people asking for an EA to be used for the Cornflower system. Now we got one and nobody seems to care. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f641.png?v=15.1)  
  
For those that care about it, here is some info about it and how I am using it:  
  
I am currently trading on 2 demo accounts – FXDD and Interbank. I was using Alpari but I decided to drop it and focus on the other 2 demo accounts.  
  
**(I am editing in the below part because for some reason it did not go through when I originally posted this message).**  
  
I am trading the 5 min chart on FXDD. I am trading only with the eur/usd with the 5 mn chart. I am testing a 15 pip SL and 30 pip target. I am using the 12 ema for the trigger (entry).  
  
WIth the Interbank platform I am trading the Cornflower on the 1 hr chart. I am testing a 30 SL and 60 target with most currencies. With the gbp/jpy I am using a 40 SL and 80 target. I decided to use the 8 ema (instead of the 12 ema) as a trigger for the 1 hr trades. Since the EA will currently take only 1 trade at a time, I have several currencies set up with the EA. This gives me better odds that it will almost always be in a trade. Because when one trade ends, hopefully another will happen very quickly.  
  
Currently we have 2 minor problems with the EA:  
  
1\. The rules state the ema's need to be in an angle for the best results for a trade. RIght now the EA wil enter all Cornflower set-ups whether or not they are in an angle. Last week I asked Postrock (the developer of the Cornflower EA) if he can make it for the ema's to be in a 20 degree angle for the trades. He said maybe he can do it this week.  
  
2\. It looks like the EA will take no more than 1 Buy trade and no more than 1 Sell trade at a time. This basically means it won't take more than 1 trade at a time (unless you are trading with more than 1 demo account ... as I am doing. Then you can take 1 trade on each demo account). Postrock said he plans on fixing it so we can trade with several currencies instead of just one.  
  
I hope he can get these problems fixed. Postrock has done a good job making the Cornflower EA. If he can fix these problems, then I will really be excited about it.  
  
  
Topgun

I am not asking for these things to be changed or for any new EA to be made but just saying what I see as problems with it for me.  
  
The angle thing may be something people use but by the nature of how Cornflower works when the EMAs are lined up the market will have been running and some angle will be present, I know they can flatten out when things are quite but often that will mean they are jumbled up and I'm not looking to trade in that situation anyway.  
  
Also one of the ways I enter a trade is by using the high/low of the bounce candle to enter, this means (at least some of the time) that trend has resumed and the market is showing this by moving back away from the bounce EMA, having this filter means not always getting in at the best price but also not getting stopped out every time price just keeps going the other way.  
  
Also what about Lever's 5min entry, also a good filter?  
  
Hope this helps

Postrock,  
  
I'm just letting you know your new EA appears to be working correctly. It has taken many trades from many different currencies - with many trades running at the same time - just as it is suppose to. ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f44d.png?v=15.1)  
  
As I mentioned from my previous post, I've been away from my computer (and had it turned off) since last Thursday. I returned home late yesterday afternoon and set up my computer to try the improved version of your EA. I have 2 demo accounts - Interbank for 1 hr chart trades and FXDD for 5 mn chart trades. Here are _my_ settings for each account:  
  
_Interbank_  
  
**Time Frame:** 1 hour  
**Trading Time:** 24 hrs a day  
**Number of currencies I am trading:** 10  
**Bar:** 0 (I do not fully understand how the "Bar" number affects a trade, so I just left it on "0".  
**MA Trigger:** 6 EMA (I am testing the 6 ema as the trigger because it always seems to work better for me than the regular CF ma's)  
**Stop Loss and Take Profit:** 30 SL & 60 TP for 9 out of the 10 currencies (the exception is the gbp/jpy of which I have a 50 SL & 100 TP)  
**trading direction:** Long & Short  
  
_FXDD_  
  
**Time Frame:** 5 min.  
**Trading Time:** from London Session open at 3am est to U.S. close at 5pm est  
**Number of currencies I am trading:** 10  
**Bar:** 0 (I have the bar at this number for the reason mentioned above).  
**MA Trigger:** 12 EMA (I decided here to use the most commonly used CF ma trigger)  
**Stop Loss and Take Profit:** 15 SL & 30 TP for 9 out of the 10 currencies (the exception is the gbj/jpy of which I have a 20 SL and 40 TP)  
**trading direction:** Long & Short  
  
  
Keep in mind that I am only testing these settings. I plan to test different stop losses and take profits, and I plan to test in order to find the best MA trigger. I also plan on testing other aspects of the Cornflower system. Another good thing to test is the "trading direction" setting (the setting is called "positions" on the EA). Right now I have my 2 demo accounts set to take all Long AND Short trades. Actually, I think the smart thing to do is to make the best estimate of the most likely direction the market is going and set the setting for that direction (example, set it "Long" if you think the market is going up for a particular trading day or session).  
  
So far in the 1 day of trading with the new EA, I have had more losses than wins. I haven't exactly calculated the dollar amount result, but it is negative amount for the 5 mn chart account, but positive amount (in profit) for the 1 hr chart account.   
  
But remember, I am totally in testing mode right now, and also it has been only 1 day of testing for me. So don't read too much into those results.  
  
  
Topgun

Glad to know someone else that is on the 5m charts.  
  
I have my ema's at 16, 24, and 43. Those have worked best for me since late last summer. I wait for them to align/stack in a direction and wait for a pullback to the 24. I will take that position but if I miss it I will take an entry at the 43 if it retraces that far.   
  
I do NOT wait for any candle to close. I enter at the moving average.  
  
My stops are typically at 25 pips. I will place as close as 20 and as far as 30 pips. This is more of a gut thing and by that I mean when I look at the chart does 20 look way to close? Does 30 pips look way too far away from entry? On more volatile days 20 will look so darn close that you know you are going to get bumped. I don't do a stop any bigger than 30 because I usually don't go for much more than that on the profit side.  
  
I take all position off of table at one exit point which is typically 20-30 pips profit. I did trade before where I scaled off to try to catch a bigger move but I realized that there is a double loss and you have to make that back up with twice as much profit. It gets too complicated at that point.  
  
I do like to target pivot points sometimes or significant S/R. Also, I will take a look at the hourly cornflower chart to see if I can target a close, longer term EMA. So, there are times when I do let a position go for much more profit but not that often.  
  
Hope this helps.  
  
God Bless.

Judging from your journal, it seems you're doing an excellent job of managing trades. It just takes patience and experience to know when to take a profit, as opposed to letting it run further. I still get tripped up sometimes myself. Letting your profits run is actually harder than cutting a losing trade. With a loser, you know the trade is over. But a winning trade can keep producing pips.   
  
When I went about developing Cornflower, my goal was exactly this: how can I get 20 pips with relative ease? Most of the time, the system will give you those pips if you follow the rules. Of course, the market may retrace and generally yank your chain before it hits that target, which is why we have to be patient and also not over-leverage ourselves. Too often we get scared out of trades that are viable because of short-term market gyrations (what I call "spaz"). If we're trading from the 1H, we need to give a trade a few hours to properly develop, and abide by our stop. And then we move that stop in the direction of our trade if it works out. Again, it takes some guts to do this. Only with hard screen time can one get a sense for the mood of the market, and then act accordingly.

Well, I just completed an exhausting move from Chicago to LA. Finally starting to settle in here. But I've had no time to follow the market of late. I hope to have more time going forward.  
  
That said, I don't post much to the thread anymore because after nearly 2 1/2 years I've more or less said all that I can say about this system. I still use it myself, and I'm glad this thread is still active. The system still works, provided you follow the rules and don't start adding unnecessary indicators (which I've found mostly useless).  
  
The only thing about this system that could be hammered out in more precise detail is when to take profit and/or loss, but I've found that there are no hard and fast rules that can be hammered out as with the entry. Cornflower can be used to either set up a scalp trade or a mid-term swing trade, and I pretty much left it up to you guys to discern what works best for you. I can assure you that there's no "secret" I've omitted. I more or less use Cornflower to gauge trend, and then move to the 5-min to enter. I've always been more of a scalp-type trader at heart, only because I don't like sitting around and waiting. If I have a profit I like to take it sooner rather than later, though on occasion I do the swing trade for 50+.   
  
Don't force your trades. Wait for a proper setup, and when it's there, take the trade.   
  
Cheers,  
Lever  
  
ps - I get these PMs from time to time asking me answer questions on Skype. Sorry y'all, but I have no time for private tutoring, and much prefer my anonymity in cyberspace.

I don't use that 15-minute entry I briefly spoke about early in the thread. It was a brief experiment that I discarded. I just use the hourly Cornflower setups in conjunction with the 5-minute, and I do this more or less as I did 2 1/2 years ago. The only thing I don't really use much anymore is the Bollinger bands on the 5-minute, only because it's another thing to look at and I don't really like distractions. If anything, my trading has become simpler. I just look for pullbacks and I watch the character of the price action.  
  
Folks, don't fret over the market. Yes, the market has been challenging over the past year, perhaps more than usual. But the market challenges us year after year anyway. It's going to do what it's going to do. All we need to do is follow the movement of price, and this is what Cornflower does.

Hi Bob, thanks for your continuing efforts to keep this thread alive. I appreciate the charts you post on a regular basis.  
  
Your question points to something I long ago lost interest in, namely predicting what the market is going to do. No one knows. All I care about is making a judgment call on what it is likely to do in the very near future, and by that, I mean in the next hour to few hours. Sometimes we are lucky to happen upon a move that lasts for days or even weeks, but the only way to get lucky in this way is to skillfully observe what is happening _right now._  
  
If price is acting funky and I'm down a few pips, I get out. If I'm up a few pips and it looks as if it's going to keep going, I stay in. If it stalls, I get out. Pretty simple stuff. I don't do the longer-term trades often, only because I don't have the personality for it. Also, I have other interests besides trading and I like to pursue them. I simply don't want to have to worry about what that silly Euro is doing every minute of the day.  
  
So. How do I know what it "looks" like it's going to do? From my experience of watching the market. I've been trading forex for several years now (with some long breaks from time to time). Watching price action is an art that takes lots of screen time to hone. I've spent countless hours in the dead of night watching the ways in which price moves, and I've developed a feel for different kinds of market conditions. Unfortunately, I've never been able to systematize this in a way that I can explain here. It's something that each trader has to learn for him or herself. Sometimes this feel leaves me for a time, much in the way athletes find themselves in a slump. I just have to trade my way out of it. But there is no contradiction between having trading rules and having a feel for price action.   
  
I hope this post makes sense...

I finally figured out the cornflower method, using the 4hr time frame and UP. I want to show you guys using only 25 bucks to turn it into 100k... This method should only be done with a second sub account. Throw away money management, risk reward, and that 2% risk only. I'm going to show you guys how to do it. It will only take 4 steps.   
  
risk 100 pip stop loss on all trades  
entry, at the beginning of the month  
tp when the monthly candle close  
  
1st step bet 1k lot or .1 micro lot until total = 150.00  
2nd step bet 1.00 pip value until you make=1,500  
3rd step bet 10.00 pip value until= 15,000  
4th step bet 100 pip value until =100k  
  
so far i only achieved step 2, but it's possible.  
  
I would do my own trading journal, but FF won’t let me yet, but cornflower method, plus fibs, trend line, PA will do the trick... who's with me... it's only 25 bucks we are risking. When the account blows up, just start over.

Hi Chace,  
  
I don't follow the GBP/JPY so I wont comment on that pair. I have taken a 1 hour chat of the USD/JPY and blacked out all the candles after the hammer in question (I'm no artist ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f612.png?v=15.1)) to give a better picture of what you might have been seeing yesterday.   
I think there are lots of things to take into consideration before placing a trade, some of the things I noticed about this set up were:  
  
That the pull back was not clean and standalone meaning that the candles before it where next to it and the hammer was in there shadow of those candles so it was not a true pull back in my opinion. Also the candles before the hammer are "allover" the EMA's  
  
There is a "whole number" not far above and you would be trading into that zone, the market had tested that level twice in the two hours before the hammer setup and had been rejected both times.   
  
I could not see an easy way into this trade using the 15 or 30 min time frames  
  
Just a few of my thoughts.

I can't see any good setups right now during the euro open so I thought I might just indulge myself and give a point or two I feel are important to keep in mind when trading.  
  
First thing is that I try not to chase trades I wait for them to come to me. Not always easy to do but the good setups stand out and I want to be trading only these good setups.  
  
Which leads me to the next thing... patience, everyone who's trading needs it and even more so with Cornflower. Trades wont always be there everyday and you sometimes just have to chill out and wait for the market to sort its self out.  
  
Just something to think about.

Chace, I don't know how may pairs you follow but it can be worthwhile looking at some extra pairs. There are two theories about this that are applicable to any type of trading...  
  
1\. Trade only 1 pair until you are very good at it, know the pair well, trade the pair well.   
  
2\. Trade a system (or even better one type of setup) when there is a setup because you know it so well you will trade it well.

Hi Chace, I don't want to get to self indulgent and give everyone my life story but yes I have been trading Cornflower for a long time. As I talked about above there are times when it seems like nothing is doing and no trades are able to be taken, I do muck around with other ideas to fill in the down time between Cornflower trends. Someone said earlier in the thread that Cornflower is slow at making money and while this could be true I have found because of its simplicity that it performs well over a long period of time. Also I have a philosophy that **the process of success is boring...** as an example an athlete who wins a gold medal may be excited at the time that they won as they should be, but its the years and years of training, getting up early, eating correctly that nobody sees which lead to the success, its not by chance. In that way success could be considered boring
